div.p: NEW EXPERIMENTS UPON VIPERS.

Containing alo an Exact DESCRIPTION Of all the Parts of a VIPER, The SEAT of its POYSON, AND THE Several EFFECTS thereof, Together with the EXQISITE REMEDIES, That by the Skilful may be drawn from Vipers, as well for the Cure of their Bitings, as for that of other Maladies.
Originally written in French By M. CHARAS of Paris.
Now rendred Englih.
div.l: Multa Patres olim: Nos plurima, plura Futuri
Invenient; Cupidis nec porta negata Novorum.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. N. for J. Martyn, Printer to the R. Society, at the Bell in S. Pauls Church-yard, and a little without Temple-Bar. 1670.

div.head: THE Preface.
div.p: MAny will perhaps wonder, that after o many famous Authours, Antient and Modern, who have written of VIPERS, I hould yet undertake to labour in an Argument, which in all likelihood they hould have exhauted. But if reflexion be made on the many wonders, that are found in the Body of this Animal, it will be eaily granted, that it cannot be inquir'd into with too much exactnes, and that it is not a work, that can be finih't at one or two ittings.

What Obervations have been left us by knowing men, although they be not carried to their perfection, may be very ueful to thoe, that are come after them, to make them dicover what had ecaped their diligence. And without this aid, I hould not have had the
confidence of undertaking this Work; in which I have propos'd to my elf three main things, that may much contribute to the illutration of the Hitory concerning Vipers. The firt is, to examine undry Obervations of the Antients, which have hitherto pas'd for true, though mot of them are not o. The econd, to give an accompt of other Obervations, which have been unknown to our Predeceors. The third, to find in the Viper, which caueth o many michiefs, Specifick Remedies againt its Biting, which had not been dicover'd before, and may erve to overcome many troubleom Ditempers, which the ordinary Remedies were not able to conquer.

The Enterprie, certainly, is bold; and, I confes, I hould never have compas'd it, what hope oever I might have conceived of it, had I not been aited by ome knowing Phyitians, whoe light hath been very helpful to me.

Their Modety permits not, I hould here name them; it ufficeth the Publick to know, that a good part of the rare things in this Treatie is due to them. They had the kindnes to meet often at my Houe for the pace of three months, and there to ee
made exact Diections of Vipers, which by my care were brought to me from all Parts of this Kingdom; and to ee alo Experiments tryed of their biting, upon divers Animals, and to examine their Bodies, immediately open'd after their death, to dicover the true caue of it; and to precribe Remedies, anwerable to their Conjectures, and to take notice of the ucces of the ame.

In diecting all thee Vipers, we were willing to ee the parts, which Authors have taken notice of, and which have alo been repreented in the Books of ome of them: And comparing them with the Natural ones, that were before our Eyes, we found great omiions of very coniderable parts; an introduction of ome imaginary ones, and repreentations and cituations of everal that were ill deigned, and ill enough placed. It was thought fit, I hould endeavour to perform omething more accomplih't: And Monieur Boe, whoe skill and dexterity in the Art of Deigning and Graving is known and eteem'd of all the World, in things of a far ublimer nature than the Anatomy of Vipers, being happily preent at one of our meetings, and taking great pleaure to oblige
his Friends, expreed from that very time, that he was very willing to econd my intentions: And having received from me a ufficient number of Subjects, hath taken the pains to deign them after the life, and thereupon to grave all the coniderable parts of this Animal. In a word, I have omitted nothing of what might render my Deign anwerable to the wihes of all Learned and Curious men.

Now as thoe, who, peaking of a matter that hath been often handled by others, cannot but mut often repeat again, what hath been already aid of it; I thought, I was not to cruple to enlarge my elf a little, that I might not give an imperfect Anatomy of the Viper, of which it was fit enough to decribe as well the great number of the true parts, that have been known to our Ancetors, as the new ones, by me found after them.

I ay nothing of my way of Writing. From a peron of my profeion, you are not to expect the Elegancy and Purity of our Tongue. I thought it enough for me, to deliver my elf clearly and intelligibly, which is, in my opinion, all that could be expected from me.

For the ret, I think, I am the firt, that hath given to France a Treatie of the Viper in its Native Language. Thoe who undertand no other Languages, may think themelves obliged by it, in regard they would ele have been ignorant of abundance of things, that deerve to be known. Farewell.

div.head: CHAPTER I.
div.p:
I Know not, what ground the Antient Writers upon this Animal had, to ay, that in the Copulation, the Male did inert his Head into the throat of the Female, and there emitted his eed, thence falling into her Matrix, where he firt did form Eggs and then Young Vipers: That the Female, finding a titillation from the emiion of the eed, napp'd off with her teeth the
head of the Male, and o kill'd him; and that the Young Vipers, being ready to be brought forth, did pierce the Womb and the ides of their Damm, to make a paage for themelves; o that by killing her, they revenged in ome manner the death of their Sire.

I confes, that this Story, or Tale rather, having neither reaon nor experience on its ide, I cannot take the part of thoe Authors. I eteem, that a Viper, which is a kind of creeping Serpent, is indeed procreated by the conjunction of Male and Female; but this is done by means of the Organs deigned for Generation; of which we hall make a decription in their proper place, and which this Animal hath common with all others, and that more in number, than mot Animals.

The Viper differs from other Serpents, not only in this, that it creeps more lowly, and jumps not; but chiefly herein, that its little ones receive their perfection in the womb, and come forth alive after the uual manner; whereas the Femals of other Serpents lay Eggs, which they incubate, and hatch, either in the Sun, or in their recees,

The Viper is by many taken for an Image of malice and cruelty; but in reality he is guilty of no uch thing, if he be not hurt or vex'd; for, if he be, he becoms furious, aud bites very piercingly: but he never aaults Man or beat, except he be angred. And if at times it happen, that he bites ome peron or other leeping in the field, certainly that Body mut have thrut or otherwie hit her; for ele he would never have bit him.

It may very well be aid, that by that means the Stratagem of Annibal ucceeded, when he caued a quantity of earthen Pitchers fill'd with Vipers to be thrown into the Shipps of the King of Pergamus, his Enemy; in regard that on the one hand the Pots being broken, did hurt and anger the Vipers, and tirr'd them up to bite whatoever was within the reach of their teeth; and on the other, the ight of thee creeping Creatures, cattered about here and there in the Ships, frighted the Souldiers and diorder'd them, o that they could not fight.

Mean time a Viper attacks and kills thoe Animals, which he means to devour for her nourihment, as Spanih Flyes, Scorpions, Froggs, Mice, Moles, Lizzards and the
like; which he wallows whole, after he hath kill'd them with her bigger Teeth. The maller prey he ends down whole into her tomach; the bigger he partly lodgeth in her tomach, partly in her weaand.

There can hardly be made any perfect digetion in the Stomach of Vipers, both becaue the heat is there not well united, by reaon of the great aperture, there is at the mouth, where the Oeophagus or Weaand ends; and becaue they have not moiture enough to help the fermentation and the Concoction of food. But yet this hinders not * the conveyance of the Juyce and of the finet part of the wallow'd animals into all the parts of their body for nourihment: Which is not performed but in the pace of many days, during which, the excrements and uperfluities of the nutriment are carried into the Gutts, whence the groer parts of them are cat out again by the mouth. This we have lately oberv'd in a great part of the body of a Lizzard, which a Viper vomited up twelve days after he was taken; where we aw, that, of the head and of the fore-leggs, and of that part of the body contiguous to them, and which
could conveniently be placed in the tomach of the Viper, there reted little more than the Bones; but that a great part of the trunk, together with the hind-leggs, and the whole taile, were in a manner in a condition, as if the Viper had wallow'd them that day, as appears in the 2d Figure. But we were urpried, among other things, to ee, that the parts, which could not enter into the tomach, and had remained in the Oeophagus, had kept o long well, I mean, without uffring any alteration in the skin; although thoe underneath had contracted ome lividnes, which perhaps was an effect of the venemounes of the biting.

Vipers can live for many months without any food, and after they are once taken, they eat no more, living then only upon the Air, they take in. And although they be greedy enough of Lizzards, when at liberty, yet I have found, that having thrown Lizzards alive into a barrel, wherein I kept a good number of living Vipers, and leaving them there whole days and nights, the Vipers did no hurt at all to the Lizzards.

The Subtance of Vipers is vicous and compact, and periheth not but very lowly
and difficultly. Their Skin is caly, which defends them from the injuries of the Air, and maketh that the Spirits unite themelves o firmly to the body, that 'tis hard for them to quit it; and we ee, that they remain yet many hours in the Head and in all the parts of the trunk, after tis flead, emptied of all the gutts, and cut in many pieces: And this is the caue, that the motions and windings o long continue in them; that the Head is able to bite, and its biting as dangerous, as when the Viper was entire; and that the Heart, even after it is pull'd out of the body, and ever'd from the other inward parts, keeps its beating for many hours. Whence it may be concluded, that the Viper, which is compoed of parts o cloely united together, and in which are found uch perfect Spirits, can impart to Man what it hath mot accompliht and in o great abundance: So that we need not wonder, if we find the remedies, we draw from its body, are of a not-ordinary vertue.

A Viper voids not much excrement, and what he voyds is not offenive, whereas that of Snakes tinks much, and hath the mell of tale and corrupt Urine. Neither
have we ever found any ill mell in opening the veels, wherein we ued to keep Vipers alive, unles ome viper or other had been dead and putrifyed. For my part, I have never received any inconvenience from any ill air, which ome pretend to iue forth at the opening of thoe Veels.

Vipers make no holes in the Earth to hide themelves in, as other Serpents do; but ordinarily they hide themelves under tones or old ruines, where they may be often found heaped up and wound together in cluters. When 'tis fair weather, they love to lurk under buhes and tufted plants.

They commonly couple twice a year, the firt time in the month of March; and they goe with their young ones 4. or 5. months; which being perfect, come forth one after another by the common opening of the Matrix, and in great number, even to twenty and twenty five. They draw out with them, in coming forth, a mall tegument fatned to their navil, like an after-birth, which the damm by little and little eparateth with her tongue, as they are born one after another.

Vipers cat a skin every Spring, and ometimes even in Autumne: which hath
occaioned a belief, that they have a vertue, able to make young again, and to preerve the trength of thoe, who ue them either for a preervative or a remedy.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Parts, which preent themelves firt.
SECT. I.
Of its external Figure.
div.p:
THe Vipers, Males and Females, that we have in France, being of their full growth, are in the middle of their body
a good inch thick; but that of Females is bigger, when they are with young, epecially when the young ones are ready to come forth. They are commonly two good foot long; and there are ome, that are omewhat longer. Their head, which is flat, hath a kind of border round about the edges of its upper part, and in that they differ from Snakes, which have all that round bared and taken down, and the Head harper and narrower, in proportion to their Body.

The Head of a Viper is in all an inch long, and towards the top thereof it is 7 or 8 lines broad; and then leening by little and little, it is not above 4 or 5 lines broad about the Eyes, and 2 lines onely about the end of the Noe. It is about 2 lines thick.

The Neck, taken where it begins, is about the bignes of a mans little finger. That of Males is ordinarily a little thicker than that of Females: Yet there are ome of the Females, which, when full, appear to have a Neck even thicker than that of Males.

The Tail of Males is always longer and thicker than that of Females, becaue it contains
the parts of generation double; and in their Intertices there are alo two mall bladders omewhat long, erving for a reervatory of their eed, which make their Tail bigger. This of the Males is about four fingers quare long; but that of Females not much longer than three. The upper part of the Taile of Males is, at its beginning, about the bignes of their Neck, and ends harp, as doth alo the Tail of Females. Neither of them tings, nor have they any venom in them.

div.head: SECT. II.
Of the Skin of Vipers.
div.p:
NO Vipers are een, but they have their skin potted: but the ground of the colour is different enough; for ometimes 'tis whitih, ometimes reddih, in ome 'tis gray, in others yellow, in others tawny. This ground is always peckled with black pots, or at leat much darker ones than the ret; they appear like different cyphers or characters, ranged in paces, even enough, and anwering one another, epecially on the top and the ides of the Body. Some of them are alo upon
the Head, and among the ret, two in the form of Horns, which take their rie between both Eyes, and open themelves and reach towards the two ides of the top of the Head, and are ometimes 4. or 5. lines long, each of them, and halfe a line broad. Oppoite to the middle of thee two horns, there appears a peck of the bignes of a mall Lentile, being haped like the Iron of a Pike: And this is that, which is, as 'twere, the firt and principal of all thee pecks, eeming to guide them all along the Back-bone.

The Skin is all cover'd with Scales, the greatet, tronget and mot coniderable of which, are thoe under the whole Body, and ome under part of the Head. Their bignes and force is neceary for them, to fortify the Viper in the place that is feeblet and leat capable of defence; beides that they upport the Animal, and erve it, intead of feet, for creeping, and for carrying its Body to and fro. Thee great Scales are alwayes of the colour of Steel, from one end to the other, and different from thoe of Snakes, which are commonly mark'd with a yellow colour. They open, and tick, according as the
Viper will recoyle, or top. The extremity of thee great Scales is, as 'twere, ow'd beneath the other little Scales, which cover the whole Body. Thoe under the Head, reach in their breadth towards the two Jawes; they are leer, treighter and ofter than thoe under the Belly, and terminate at other maller Scales, which go on to cover the whole undermot part of the Head, and, beginning their ranks towards the ends before, continue them at the ides of thoe ranks as far as towards the bottom of the Jaws.

From the beginning of the Neck unto the beginning of the Tayl, there are as many great Scales, as there are vertebraes or Joynts of the Back-bone; and as each Vertebra hath on each ide a Ribb, each Scale meets by its two ends the points of both, and erves them for a defence and tay: the ame abuts alo on each ide at the end of one rank of litle cales, wherewith the ret of the Body is covered, and it eems, that 'tis placed there to receive them. Thee mall cales are admirably well ranged, they lying upon one another, and repreenting each as 'twere halfe a round towards their extremity. Their ranks appear
always loping, whether you look on them from the right ide to the left, or from the left to the right; ome what after the manner of the ranks of mall Slate, that are cut in a halfe round, in ome places een in olthe tops of houes. Thee Scales are more or les great, according as the part of the Body, they cover, is greater or leer. The Symmetry of them is always very exquiite and even; and is utable to the great Scales, united to their ranks beneath. There are alo oberv'd on the top of thee Scales, and all along the Back, many fine and ditinct Lines, paing treight along from the hind-part of the Head unto the end of the Tayl.

The Scales, that are under the Tayl from the beginning of it to the end, are divided, and yet they appear united and ranged in the middle by a very orderly and pleaing compartment; and their bignes goes diminihing in proportion with the Tayl.
The Skin of the Head is alo covered with mall cales, and at the end of the Noe turned up, and o on, even round about, as far as towards the Eyes, in the manner of a wines-nout.

There are oberved only ix openings in
the Skin of a Viper: the bigget is that of its Throat; the other four are thoe of the two Notrils, and of the two Eyes; the lat is that, which is at the lower-mot end of the Belly, where is the beginning of the Tayl, which incloeth not only the hole of the Gut for voiding the excrements, but alo thoe of the organs of Generation, as well of Males as Females. This lat opening is hut by the lat of the great cales, which is advanc'd in the form of a half round, and opens in falling lower at the time of copulation, as it alo doth at the time of the young Vipers being cat, and of the excretion of their dung. The Throat opens and huts at the will of the Animal; the Notrils remain alwayes open, and the Eyes have Eye-lids to cover them upon occaion. There is no aperture in the skin to give any paage for Hearing; Nature, it eems, erving herelf of the apertures of the Notrils for that purpoe.

Vipers ordinarily cat their caly Skins twice a year, under which they are furniht with another, quite formed, which at firt appears much fairer, and of a more vivid colour, than that which is cat off. And there is alo inenibly forming an other
new one, againt the time it is to erve, when that which now covers it hall be evered from it: So that a Viper hath at all times a double skin; and all thee skins, though furniht with cales, are notwithtanding tranparent, being held and look't on againt the day-light.

This External decription might be ufficient for thoe, who hall deire no more but to know how to dicern Vipers from other Serpents, but the Anatomical Decription of all the parts under the Skin will be much more atisfactory and more neceary for thoe, who hall deire to know exactly all the good and all the ill in a Viper.

div.head: CHAP. III.
OF the Parts of the Head OF A VIPER
SECT. I.
Of the Noe and Notrils.
div.p:
BEginning at the extremity of the Head there are the Noe and the Notrils. The former is made up of a Bone ome what Gritly, furniht with ome ends of Mucles, that come farther off, and are accompanied with ome mall veins and arteries. This Bone is alo cover'd with the caly Skin, turn'd up, as was aid above, at its extremities. There are two pipes, in the two ides, that form the notrils, which have each a mall and round opening on the right and the left ide, before, and the proper nerve, which coms down
from the fore-part of the Brain unto their Orifice, and communicates to them the objects of melling. The ame Pipes erve alo to receive two mall Nerves, which iue each from the lateral part of the Brain, and erve for Hearing. This gritly Bone hath everal Angles round about, and is articulated by two trong Ligaments within and about the hollow and anteriour part of the Skull; which hinders not, but that it is a little flexible in this Articulation.

div.head: SECT. 2.
Of the Skull.
div.p:
THe Skull is found hollow in the forepart of it, and repreents the hape of an Heart in this Cavity, when the Bone of the Noe is eparated from it. There are two points advancing, which in part embrace that Bone; it is in the uperior part urrounded with a mall border, advancing in the fahion of a Cornihe; it is notch'd on both ides, where the Eyes are cituate, and there forms their round holes, of which the hind-part reaches out to a point, to which anwers that before. The whole Skull in
all its parts is of a very compact and hard ubtance. There are three principal Sutures in the part above; the one, which may be call'd the Sagittal, which divides longwayes the part above the two Eyes; the econd, which may be term'd Coronal, divides the Skull a-cros behind the two Eye-holes; the third, eparates it alo cros-ways near the beginning of the Back-bone. In the Surface of the upper part of the Skull, may be oberv'd the figure of an Heart well repreented, eated in the middle thereof, which hath its bais near the Suture Coronal, and carries its harp end towards the hind-part of the Skull, which is ever'd by the third Suture.

There is alo another great Suture, round about the nethermot lateral parts of the Skull, by which it may be divided into two bodies, an upper and lower. This latter is made in the form of a turn'd back, going long wayes, hollow in the middle, and repreenting the hape of a Culter, which hath a kind of little wing on its ides, and whoe point advances beneath the middle of the Eyes. Its latter part decends as far as the bottome of the Palate, where it hath in its lower part a point
decending in the form of an overturn'd hillock.

All the Sutures of the Skull are o well united in their conjunction, and o trongly connected, that 'tis very hard to ditinguih them, and yet more to eparate the parts of them without breaking them, unles the Skull be boyled in ome liquor.

div.head: SECT. 3.
Of the Brain.
div.p:
THe ubtance of a Vipers Brain is divided into five main Bodies, of which the two firt are oblong, each of the ize and hape of a grain of Succory-eed. They are eated long-wayes between the two Eyes; and 'tis from thee Bodies, that the Olfactory Nerves do proceed. The three other are in the middle part of the Skull, and under that figure of the Heart, of which we have been peaking. Each of thee Bodies is near as big as a grain of the Seed of Milium Solis, and repreents almot the hape of a Pear, the point of which is turned towards the fore-part of the Head. Two of thee Bodies are eated in the upper
part long-wayes, and one on the ide of the other; the third, which is a little les, is placed under the middle of the two, and may be call'd the Cerebellum, or little Brain.

The Spinal Marrow eems to be the ame body with this lat, although it have a eparate place in the hind-part of the Skull. It is of a ubtance omewhat whiter and ofter than the Bodies, we have been jut now peaking of, and of the ize of a mall grain of Wheat. It produces a Body of the ame ubtance, which extends it elf long-wayes, and paing in a trait line thorough all the Vertebra's or Joints of the Back-bone, terminates at the end of the Tayle.

The Bodies of a Vipers Brain are cover'd with a coat, thick enough, and ticking fat enough to them, which may be called the Dura Mater.: It is black, whence it hath hapned, that ome Authors, not taking the pains to look under this Tunicle, have affirm'd, that Vipers Brains were black. Under this Dura Mater, each Body of the Brain, eparately, hath alo a little membrane involving it, which may be termed the Pia Mater. There are oberved ome mall intertices betwixt thee Bodies, and
even in the Body of the Spinal Marrow, which might pas for Ventricles: And I doubt not, but that, if the Subject were a little bigger, we might oberve in it mot of the coniderable parts, that are to be found in bigger Animals.

div.head: SECT. 4.
Of the Eyes, and their principal parts; as alo of thoe, that erve for Hearing.
div.p: THe Eyes of Vipers are very quick, and their apect is exceedingly fixt and bold. They have their Nerves, Mucles, Veins, Arteries, Apple, Chrytallin, Uvea, Cornea, Eye-lids, and the other parts, like enough to thoe of the Eyes of other Animals.

The mot coniderable Nerves are the Optick, which parting from behind both the Eyes, do meet together and conjoin laterally at the beginning of the Little Brain, and there make as it were the figure of an X, and opening themelves after this conjunction, they encompas that little Body by the ides thereof, and render themelves at
the beginning of the Spinal Marrow, which receives them.

The mallnes of all the other parts being uch, as that it maketh their examination difficult, and we having not been able to find any thing particular in them, I eteem, that as it would be very troubleome to make Reearches thereof, o it would be to no purpoe, to make a decription of them.

The two upper Bodies of the Brain end each from their lateral fore-part a mall Nerve, which piercing the Skull, runs along the Temples, where it joins it elf to the Salival Glands (whereof we hall peak hereafter) and following them, it paeth under the Eye, where it divideth it elf into two branches, of which the chief inerts it elf into the Bone and the Conduit of the Notrils, to erve for the Sene of Hearing, and the leer decending towards the Teeth, called the Dog-teeth, it ends there, after it hath divided it elf into everal branches.

div.head: SECT. 5.
Of the Bones of the Head, that are jointed to the Skull.
div.p: ON each upper ide of the middle of that Heart, which is een above in the Skull, there is a little flat Bone, a matter of a line and an half long, that is firmly articulated to it, which following and adhering to the ame ide of the Skull as far as to its hind-part, becomes to be articulated anew to another flat Bone, longer and tronger, and forming there as 'twere an Elbow. This latter Bone goeth downwards, and is trongly jointed to the inward end of the lower Jaw; in the middle of which articulation, the upper Jaw terminates, and is there jointed, but not o firmly, becaue it hath other articulations, which the lower hath not. Thee Bones, which are like Clavicles, erve both for a upport to the Jaws, and to open and hut them; and for this purpoe they are aited by the Nerves and Mucles, which Nature hath provided them with.

There is alo at each advancing end of the Eye-hole a little flat Bone, being about a line and an half long, which is trongly articulated with the root of the Dogtooth, and by its other end is alo firmly jointed to the middle of the upper Jaw, as well to upport it, as to make it advance together with the great Tooth, when it is raied to bite.

The upper Jaw is divided in two, before, and is eparated, by the gritly Bone, from the Noe, where its two ends are articulated on each ide. Thee two Jaws are much more inward than thoe below, and the great Teeth are eated without their rank and at their ide, tending outward, and do erve them for a defence. They are made up, each of one only Bone, that is about ix lines long.

The lower Jaw is alo divided in two. Thee Jaws are annexed, before, one to the other, by a Mucle, which opens or huts them at the pleaure of the Animal; and they have no other articulation but that, we have poken of about their inward end, viz. with the Clavicle coming down from the Skull, and with the inward end of the upper Jaws. Each of thee
Jaws is compoed of two Bones, articulated together towards the middle of the Jaw; that which is before, embraces above and below that which is behind, and can bend it elf outward in this place, when the Viper will bite, and is a little curved inwards toward its extremity; and 'tis upon this Bone alone, that the lower Teeth are fatned.

div.head: SECT. 6.
Of the Teeth.
div.p:
THe Opinions of the Antients have been very differing about the number of the great Teeth of Vipers, and mot have held, that in this the Female exceeded the Male, and that the plurality of the great Teeth was the chief mark, whereby to ditinguih her from him. I have been careful to inform my elf about it, and have taken pains to grovel with a great deal a patience in the gums of innumerable Vipers; but all being well examined, I have not found, as to this point, any true difference of one Sex from the other, but ometimes more, ometimes les Teeth in one and the
other. I have caually met on each ide with two great Teeth fixed, placed very near together, and on the ide of one another, as well in Males, as Females; but in mot of both Sexes I have found only one, fixed on each ide, cover'd, to two thirds of their height, with a Tunicle or Bag ufficiently thick, fill'd with a yellowih juyce, which is tranparent and pretty fluid; and in this Veicle, in the midt of this juyce, and under the great and main Teeth, a differing number of Teeth ill et, ome longer than others, and all hooked, of which I have counted, in everal Vipers, from two to five, ix and even, on one and the ame ide, under the elf-ame Tooth, and in the ame Bag.

Thee great Teeth are only in the upper part, tanding on the ide, and without the Jaws of the Animal, where they are like Bulwarks. They are about two lines long, hooked, white, hollow, and diaphanous throughout, as far as to their harp point, which is very ubtle and exceedingly piercing. They have many little Cavities towards their Root, in which the other Teeth are planted. Thee Teeth commonly remain lying along the Jaw, and
their point appears not but at the moment the Viper will bite; for then it raieth them, and advanceth them jointly with the upper Jaw, drawn by the Bone, which at one end is articulated in the middle of it, and at the other, to the root of the great Tooth.

The yellow liquor, contained in the Veicle, erveth not only to moiten the ligaments, and to make them fit for the bending of the Teeth, but alo to nourih them, and to make thoe grow, that are there as 'twere in a Nurery, and are, if we may ay o, in expectation to erve intead of the many Teeth, whether thee come to fail in their force, or fall out of themelves.

All the Jaws, both upper and lower, are fortify'd with bent Teeth, that are hollow, pellucid and harp, as the bigger Teeth, but that they are much maller. Their number is uncertain enough, whether it be, that Nature produces ometimes more, ometimes les of them, or that that finenes maketh them apt to break. There is little difference, as to the number, in thoe above from thoe below. Ordinarily there are eight Teeth in each Jaw, but at times I have found nine, ten, eleven in each. Thoe
that advance mot, are a little bigger than the deepet; and jut as thoe below anwer in cituation to the Dog-teeth, that are above them, they have at the end of each ide one Tooth, that is a little bigger than all thoe of the other Jaws, and another, leer, at the ide, at the end of the part bent inwards.

There is a great difference in the Teeth and Jaws of Vipers, from thoe of Snakes: for, thee have no Dog-teeth; and although their Jaws are all divided in their foremot part like as in Vipers, yet they exceed them in the number of Jaws, and in the number of Teeth; for, they have four Jaws above, and two below; two of thoe above are ituated all along and cloe to the rim of the Lip, and erve for a defence to the two other Jaws, that are eated in the ame place, where thoe in Vipers are. Beides, I have counted 13 Teeth in each exterior Jaw above, and as many in each of the Jaws below, and 20 in each uperior inward Jaw; o that I have counted of them to 92 Teeth in one Snake, and all thee Teeth are bent, fine, hollow, white and tranparent, like thoe in Vipers.

div.head: SECT. 7.
Of the Nerves, Veins, Arteries and Mucles of the Head in general.
div.p: THe chief Nerves in the Head of a Viper are, firt, thoe of which we have poken, namely thoe of the Smell, the Sight and the Hearing. Beides, there are thoe of the Tate, that which may be call'd the ixth par vagum, which is afterwards ditributed into all the vital and natural parts; and thoe, which iuing from the Spinal Marrow are carried through the whole habit of the Body. There are alo many Nerves, that go from the inferiour part of the Brain, and pas through the Skull, but by reaon of their ubtility and finenes, 'tis hard to follow them to their inertion.

There is yet another Nerve that is coniderable, which proceeds from the Skull, behind that of Hearing, which leaves, in the pace between, a mall Apophyis, or Proces, or Knot, in the Skull, and which, decending along the Clavicle, runs upon the uperiour Jaw, and is inerted in its middle;
then it goes on in the middle to its extremity, and ditributeth it elf into all the Teeth, fix'd there.

The Head hath alo its Veins and Arteries, which coming from the Liver and the Heart, ditribute themelves there into an infinity of branches, by which all thoe parts are bedew'd. It is alo provided of many Mucles, at the ides and below the Skull, and about the Clavicles, and uperiour and inferiour Jaws, that erve not only to fill up the Cavities of the Skull, and to cover the Bones that are articulated there, but to give motion to all the parts that need it: to which alo the Nerves contribute their hare.

div.head: SECT. 8.
Of the Salival Glands of a Viper.
div.p:
THe Opinion of the Antients, That the eat of the Vipers poyon was the Gall, and that from thence it acended into the Gums, by veels odly enough fancied, hath eem'd to me too far from all probability to follow it. I therefore thought, that that particular did very well
deerve a trict enquiry, and that it was of moment to dicover the Truth thereof. On the other ide, the curious Obervations, made on this Subject by Signor Redi, a Florentine Philoopher, whoe merit is known and eteem'd by all the Learn'd, eemed to me, as to all thoe that have een and examin'd them, not only reaonable and poible, but I was altogether perwaded of the candor and ability of that illutrious peron. Upon his Accompt and Relation, I never crupled to tate often of the gall of Vipers, as well as of the yellowih liquor, contained in the bags of the Gums; and I have found in both the Truth of what he hath oberved thereof, namely a great bitternes, and a great harpnes in the Gall; and the tate of a Saliva or Spittle ufficiently flat, and approaching enough to the tate of the Oyle of weet Almonds, in the yellow Liquor of the Gums.

Thee great differences of the qualities in the one from the other, made me believe that there was a great diverity in the matter of them, as well as in their ource; and I believed at firt, following Signor Redi, that there might be Salival Veels in Vipers,
as there have been lately found in Man, and divers other Animals; o that after many reearches, made with attention and patience enough, in many Vipers Heads, I dicover'd at length uch Glands, proper to form this juyce, and to convey it to the Gums; and after I was well perwaded of it my elf, I hew'd them to divers of thoe knowing Phyitians, that had met at my Houe the lat Year. Thee perons had a mind to ee with their own Eyes, and after they had well examin'd the parts which I hew'd them, they not only found them true, but they there alo aw a greater number of maller veels, than had appear'd to me, of which ome, that are Arteries and Veins, pas above the Glands, and others, that are Lympheducts, run below: o that they judged, that I could confidently aert and decribe thee Glands, which I call Salival, and which they had acknowledged together with me; though Signor Redi durt not peak poitively of them, becaue he had not dicover'd them, neither had they been decribed by any Author of their knowledge, nor by any one of mine.

Thee Glands are found in all the Heads of Vipers, both Males and Females; they are eated on both ides, and joining to the Skull, in the hind-part of each round of the Eyes, and at the ame height with them. There are many mall ones join'd together, which may be call'd Conglomerate Glands, which are eaily ditinguihable by their form and colour, which is different from the Mucles, neighbouring to them, and of which there is one, that may be call'd Temporal, which in part covers them by its extremity. This heap of Glands appears there of the bignes of the neighbouring Eye, and extending it elf in length, continues its progres in the Orbite of the Eye, below, and in part behind the Eye. Each Gland hath its little Lymphatique Veel, which parts from it as from a little Teat, and goes digorging it elf into a greater Veel, that runs all along and under thee Glands, and paeth into the Veicle of the Gum, and terminates in the midt of the Articulation, which the root of the great Teeth maketh with the advancing corner of the aid Orbite, and with the little Bone, which by its other end is articulated in the middle of the upper Jaw. This
principal veel, which, being conidered alone, is very little in appearance, but is not o in effect, eing it receives the dicharge of all the mall veels, that come from each Gland, empties it elf into the Bag of the Gums, and carries thither that Salival Juyce, which may have qualities approaching to thoe of the Saliva or Spitle of man, or of the foam or drivel of divers other Animals.
The Nerve, which erves in the Notrils for the faculty of Hearing, runs for ome pace along thee Glands, which are alo, as I have already aid, mal Veins and Arteries.

But having well conidered the ubtance, quality, and ituation of thee Glands, we judged their formation not to be in vain; but that their Ue, in all likelyhood, was to receive the humidities both of the Brain, the Eyes, and the neighbouring parts; and that their dicharge was very convenient and even very neceary to the parts, which receive that liquor, as well for moitening the ligaments of the great Teeth, and to keep them in a condition of bending, at uch time when the Viper will bite, and to increae the
Teeth, which Nature hath made and et in the midt of this Juyce.

For the ret, examining and tating the Glands as well as the Juyce, we found a Tate altogether like that of the Gums, which Signor Redi hath decribed, namely very near the tate of the Oyle of Almonds, without any bitternes, though it leave, a while after, a little acrimony in the mouth, uch as may be dicerned in all kind of Spitle.

As to the mall Glands, which Signor Redi hath oberved at the bottom of the Veicles that contain this Juyce, I can ay, that I have with great care and diligence earched them, and that, 'tis true, I have there found the appearances of Glands, but having opened them, I aw nothing in them but mall teeth which were fatned there, and are of the number of thoe, which I have called Expectants, without finding any thing of a Glandular nature there, nor that did, in the leat, approach to the hape, ubtance or qualities of the Glands, which I have been decribing.

The Viper is not the onely among Serpents, that hath Salival Glands; for I have
alo found of them in the Head of Snakes, which Glands were heaped together longwayes, and cituated near each outward upper Jaw, erving them for a defence, in a manner, as the Dog-teeth do to Vipers.

Thee coniderations, upported by many Experiments, made by us, and to be related hereafter, have induced me to call thee Glands Salival, and to acribe to them the very ource of that yellow Liquor, which hath been o much decryed, and with-all o little known, and is nothing ele, but a pure and very innocent Spittle. I hope, that thoe, who hall take the pains of carefully examining, after me, thee Glands, and this juyce of the Gums will not tick to give me their uffrages.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the other Bones of a VIPER, and the principal Parts, thence depending.
div.p:
THe great number of Bones, which ret in the Body of a Viper after thoe of the Head, conits only in the Vertebra's or Joints of the Back-bone, and the Ribs. Thee Joints begin at the hind-part of the Skull, to which the firt is articulated; the other are ranged conecutively, trongly joined to one another, and they continue to the end of the Tayle. Every Viper, both Male and Female, hath an hundred and forty five Vertebra's, from the end of the Head to the beginning of the Tayl, and Two hundred and fourcore and ten Ribs, which is the double number of the Vertebra's; to each of which there are articulated two Ribs, one to each ide, which are bent, and do
embrace the vital and natural parts of a Viper, and each point whereof rendevoues at one of the ends of the great Scale under the belly, which is fit for both; o that there are as many great Scales under the belly, from the end of the Head unto the beginning of the Tayle, as there are Vertebra's, conorted by their two Ribs: Beides that, there are twenty five Vertebra's from the beginning of the Tayle to the end thereof; and thoe Vertebra's have not any Ribs, but, intead thereof, little Apophyes, or Procees, which leen in their magnitude, as the Vertebra's do, tending towards the extremity of the Tayle.

There are four great Mucles, very firm and very long, which take their origine from the hind-part of the Head, and decend, two of them on each ide of the Spinal Procees, one joining to the Spine, and the other to the ide and a little below the firt, which it accompanies all along unto the end of the Tayle. There are alo two great Mucles of the like length, which are fatn'd to the inferiour part of the Vertebra's, and accompany them from one end to the other, as well as the uperiour ones. We alo oberve, on each ide, as many intercotal
Mucles, as there any Vertebra's, erving for the ame ue, that thoe of other Animals do, which ever the Ribbs from the place of their root unto their point All thee Mucles are alo accompanied with veins and arteries, as well as the greatet.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the other Internal parts of a Viper.
SECT. 1.
Of the Tongue.
div.p:
THe Tongue, which the Viper darts out and draws in often and very quick, preents her elf firt of all. She is placed between the two Jaws below, and compoed of two Bodies, flehy, long and roundih, and terminating in very harp and flexible points. Thee two Bodies are contiguous, and adhere to one another all along, from the place <>
their root as far as to the two third parts of their length. The inward half of thee Bodies is of the colour of fleh, but the other half, I mean that which is often thrut out, is of colour blackih.

The Tongue may be, in all, an inch and an half long. Its root begins half an inch
lower than the bottom of the Throat; and 'tis firmly annex'd, below the Neck, to two tendinous bodies, which are two or three lines long.

There are ome Vipers, whoe Tongues have three points, and ome alo, that have four. Thee points, though often darted out, prick not, nor hurt any body; though perhaps they may frighten the ignorant. They chiefly erve Vipers to catch thee mall creatures, which they have a mind to devour. The Tongue is envelop'd by a kind of heath from one end to the other.

div.head: SECT. 2.
Of the Wind-pipe and the Lungs.
div.p:
THe Wind-pipe hath its beginning at the entrance of the Throat, where it preents a hole in an Oval, raied on high, and having as 'twere a little beak in its lower part. It is compoed, at its entrance, of many gritly rings, joyned to one another; which continue about the length of a good inch, and fall into the right ide of the Viper, where they meet with the Lungs; and from that place you ee no more but the
half rings turn'd upide down, which being joyned on both ides to the membrans, that depend from the Lungs, and which are annexed to it below from one end to the other, being aited by the aid Lungs, erve for Repiration, and continue their rank and their connexion, as far as to the fourth part of the Liver, which lies under it; as well as the Heart. The Winde-pipe is in all eight or nine inches long; and at the place, where its half rings end, it is united with a membrane, which attracts and receives the Air, as far as to the beginning of the intetins, where it forms, as it were, a roundih bottom of a ack.

The Lungs, being joyn'd to the Wind-pipe, and making with it one Body, are conequently ituate, as it, on the right ide. They begin, where the whole rings of the Winde-pipe do end. They are made in the form of a Net; they have no Lobes at all, they are red, very clear and very vivid, of a ubtance fine enough, ufficiently tranparent, and a litle rough. They are fatned by Membrans to the upper part of the imperfect rings; being even or eight inches long, and about one inch broad; and all over embroidered with veins and arteries.

div.head: SECT. 3.
Of the Heart, and the Liver.
div.p: THe Heart and the Liver are alo eated on the right ide of the Viper; and before the Heart there is, about the third part of an inch, a little flehy and flattih body, of the bignes of a little pea, which is filled with water; this little body is placed under the Lungs as well as the Heart and the Liver, and is upended by the ame membrans, which upport it: it may be taken for a kind of Thymus or kernel, and may erve for the ame ues.

The Heart is eated about four or five inches below the beginning of the Lungs; of the bignes of a mall beane: it is omewhat long, flehy, and encompaed with its pericardium, which conits of a ufficiently thick tunicle. It hath two Ventricles, one on the right, the other on the left ide: it alo hath two apertures. The Blood, which comes from the vena cava, enters into the right ventricle, and being paed into the left, iues thence by the Aorta, which preently is divided into two great
branches, one of which acends into the upper parts, and the other, paing below the Oeophagus or Weand, and taking its way loping, ubdivideth it elf afterwards into many other branches, which pread themelves and are carried to all the parts, to the very end of the Tayle.

The Liver is a flehy part, of colour redbrown, eated half an inch beneath the Heart, and upported by the ame membrans: its length and breadth are unequal enough, but the greatet Livers, I have een, are five or ix inches long, and half an inch large. It conits of two great lobes of which the right decends a good inch lower then the left. Thee two lobes are bedew'd by the vena cava, which eems to eparate them all along into two bodies, and which makes even a eparation in their lower half, running in their intertice, and erving to joyn them together in one body: The upper half of the Liver is continued, and cannot be divided but by cutting it aunder.

The Trunk of the vena cava is divided into two branches in its upper part, of which the main and bigget endeth in the Heart, and the other paeth under the
Lungs, and from thence into the uperiour parts. This Vein in its inferiour part is divided into many branches, which decend into all the parts below.

A Viper is detitute of a Diaphragme, there being no olid travering tunicle at all, that evers the vital parts from the natural: yet it may be aid that that fine tunicle, which depends from the Windpipe and the Lungs, and goes down towards the Intetins, and there forms, as 'twere, the hape of a ack-bottom, may in ome manner peform the function thereof.

div.head: SECT. 4.
Of the Gall, and the Pancreas, which the Antients called the Spleen.
div.p: THe Bladder of Gall is ituate an inch below the Liver, and on the ide of the bottom of the Stomack, and it leans to the left ide. It is almot of the hape and bignes of a mall Bean lying flat.
The Gall is very green; its tate very bitter and harp; its conitence approaching to that of a Syrup not much boyled.

I have found in the Bladder of Gall but one out-let by a mall veel, which iuing from the inward ide of its upper part, is bent from its origine, and decending, and adhering, even in its beginning, to the internal part of this Bladder, is afterwards divided into two branches, of which the principal and directet, paing through that Body (which the Antients have taken for the Spleen) runs into the Intetin, which receives it; and the other leer branch, turning about, eems to remount to the Liver, but dividing itelf into many mall branches, becomes o indicernable, that it cannot be followed any longer.

It is not here, that I will refute the opinion of the Antients concerning the Venomous quality they have acribed to the Gall; I leave that for another place, where I hall endeavour to maintain the Balamique quality of this Juyce, and hew, that 'tis free from all kind of poyon.

The Pancreas or Sweet-bread, which all Authors have called the Spleen, is placed near and a very little below the Gall, and on the right ide of the Viper. It is of the bignes of a good Pea, of a eemingly flehy ubtance, but indeed Glandular. Conidering its ituation (which is cloe to the bottom of the Stomach and towards the entry of the Guts) together with its kernelly ubtance, it maketh me believe, that 'tis rather a Pancreas than a Spleen: but yet I leave the deciion of it to thoe, who hall take the pains to examine it.

div.head: SECT. 5.
Of the Oeophagus or Weaand, and the Stomach.
div.p: THe Oeophagus takes its beginning at the bottom of the Throat; its ituation is on the left ide, and its paage directly on the ide of the Lungs and the Liver, as far as to its union with the orifice of the Stomach. It is made up of one onely membrane, very oft, and eay to be extended, and which may be well'd even to the bignes of two inches. It is this part, which firt receives the animals, the Viper hath killed with its great teeth, and wallowed whole, it being proper for that purpoe, both by its large capacity, and by its length, which is of a good foot.

The Stomack, which is next, is as 'twere owed at its bottom, and eems to make but one Body with the Oeophagus; but yet is much thicker, and compoed of two trong coats, one within the other, and ticking to one another. The thicknes of its coats makes, that it cannot be well'd to the ame bignes with the Oeophagus;
for it cannot much exceed the bignes of an inch. It is between three and four inches long; its orifice is ufficiently large, as well as its middle, but the bottom of it grows treighter, and is commonly very cloe and firm, not opening it elf, but to eject its excrements into the Gutts. Its internal tunicle is full of rugoities when 'tis empty, and in it there are very often found little worms of the length and thicknes of mall pins. The Stomach is eated on the left ide, as the Oeophagus; but the bottom of it is turned towards the middle of the Body, to empty itelf into the firt Gut.

The length and capacity of the Oeophagus, and the largenes of the entry of the Stomach, are very well accommodated to the-nature of the Viper, which ends nothing chew'd to the Stomach, but wallows Animals whole for its food; and when ome of them happen to be longer than the depth of the Stomach, part of them tayes in the Oeophagus, untill the Stomach have extracted and ent away the juyce of the parts devoured, which it could hold; after which it receives thoe that tay'd in the Oeophagus. But this requires a good pace
of time, in regard that the Stomach is not cloed, and cannot gather any coniderable heat to make a peedy digetion.

div.head: SECT. 6.
Of the Intetins, kidneys, Fat, and a Tunique wrapping them up below.
div.p: THE Intetins of Vipers are ituate in the midt of the Body, under the Back-bone, and immediately after the bottom of the Stomach. I have onely oberved three of them, of which the firt and narrowet may be called the Duodenum; the econd, which is larger, and full of many windings, may be called the Colon; and the third and lat, the Rectum, which alo is very large and very treight; and hath its aperture below and near the beginning of the tayle, at which the Excrements pas away.

Thee Intetins have, at their ides, Teticles, together with their veels, both of
the Males and Females, and the two bodies of the Matrix of the latter, which we hall peak of hereafter. They contain alo the kidnys with their veels, which part from thence, and are accompanied of their veins and arteries, as alo all veels erving for generation; and the Intetins themelves are not detitute of them.

The kidneys are placed below the Teticles; they are made up of many glandulous bodies, contiguous, and ranged longwayes, one after another. They are commonly two inches and an half long, and two l • nes and an half large upon the round, which is a little flat. They are of a pale-red colour. The right kidney is alwayes eated higher than the lower in both exes. They have alo their Ureters, at which they dicharge the eroities near the extremity of the Intetin.

All the Intetins, the Teticles, and the kidneys are covered with a very white and very oft Fat, which being melted hath the form of Oyle. At times alo there is een in ome Vipers a little Fat about the Heart, the Lungs, the Liver, but epecially cloe to the Gall, and near that part, which ome take for the Spleen, and others
for the Pancreas. All thee parts are wrapped about with a trong Coat, that is firmly fatned to the extremities of the Ribbs, which might pas for the Epiploon, if the Fat were joyned to it: but as the Viper, which is a kind of Serpent, paeth not but among the imperfect animals, I hall not determine the name of this Tunique, to which the more Intelligent may give what name they hall think mot proper.

div.head: CHAPT. VI.
Of the parts of Vipers, that erve for Generation.
SECT. 1.
Of the Parts of the Male.
div.p:
THE Male hath two Teticles, which are omewhat long and roundih, and harpen a little toward both ends. Their colour is white, and their ubtance glandular. Their length is unequal, the right being longer by an inch, than the left, and this alo omewhat les in thicknes. They are not thicker than the quill of the wing of a great Capon. Their ituation is different; for, the right begins near and beneath the Gall, whereas the left begins about eight lines lower than the right. They are both upended in their upper part by two trong membrans, coming from below the
Gall, and are ordinarily covered with fat, which maketh them hardly dicernable, by reaon of the likenes of colour they have with this fat.

From the midt of each of thee Teticles, from the inward part, one may ee iue forth a little Body, long and lender, olid enough, and even omewhat whither than the ubtance of the Teticles, which decends, and is fatned to them all along as far as to their lower end. It may be called the Epididymis. There appears at the end of each, the beginning of a mall tradling veel, that may be called permatique becaue of its office; which is a little flat, very white, and hining enough, and commonly filled with eed, having the form of a milky juyce. This veel is ufficiently delicate, and winds in its paage, after the hape of many Ss joyned together, very pleaant to behold. From thence it decends between the Intetin and the kidney, whoe Ureter it follows unto the hole of the lat Gut, at which the Excrements pas away. It is alo accompanied of veins and arteries from one end to the other, as well as the Teticles, and it ceaeth to be winding a little before it comes to the aperture
of the Gut. Each of thee two permatique veels comes to rendevoue at its proper receptacle of eed; of which there are two, that may be called Paratates, which are like white kernels, each of the length, bignes and hape of a grain of Carduus benedictus eed. Thee kernels are eated longways below and between the two natural parts: they are always full of a milky juyce, and altogether like that of the permatique veels, jut now decribed: and to furnih for ejaculation at the time of the Coitus, they tranmit the eed, which they contain, into the ejaculatory pipes of the two natural parts, neighboring to them.

I may ay on this occaion, that thoe who have taken thee two Conervatories of eed for other Teticles, have much deceived themelves in the opinion, they have entertained, that, there being two natural parts, there mut alo be for each of them two teticles: But their ubtance being quite different from the true teticles, by us decribed, and their office being to receive, and not to form, we do not acknowledge them but for Paratates, which by little and little receive the Seed, ent thither by the Teticles, and reerve
it, and keep it ready for the time of copulation, and to perform that in a moment, and eaonably, what the permatique Veels would not be able to execute o oon, nor o well, becaue of their length and windings.

The Male hath two Penes's altogether alike, which being pulled out are each as long as the Tayl of the animal. Their origine cometh from the extremity of the Tayle, under which they are eated all along, the one by the other. They go increaing in bignes, as the Tayle does; at the beginning of which they end, and they have their iue near and at the ide of one another, and cloe to the opening of the Intetin, which maketh in a manner their eparation.

Each of thee is compoed of two long and fitulous bodies, eated together one by the other, and which joyn towards their top in one body, which is environed with its prepuce, and hath its Mucles Erectors, as many other Animals have. Thee parts are within full of many tings or pricks, very white and hard, and very harp, o et, as that they have their harp end variouly turned; of which the bignes and thicknes
anwers to the place of the natural part, where they are et, o that as the top is bigger and thicker, the aid tings are o too; and they advance and appear not but when the prepuce, which covers them, hrinks down at the time of the animals dipoition to the coit.

Thee natural parts are ordinarily hidden, and they well not, nor come forth, but for the coit; unles it be, that, the animal being taken, they be forced out by preing them; for in that cae one may ee them both come forth equally, each about the thicknes of a date, and of the length of two thirds thereof, and their top is altogether covered and quite beet with thee pricks, like the skin of a Porcupin; and thee tings retire and hide themelves under the prepuce, when one ceaeth to pres them.

The iue of thee two parts is environ'd with a very trong and thick Mucle, to which the skin is firmly fatned, and in uch a manner that it is very difficult to eparate it therefrom: which ame Mucle erveth alo to open and hut the Intetin.

div.head: SECT. 2.
Of the parts of the Female Viper, that erve for Generation.
div.p:
THe Femal Viper hath two Teticles, as the Male; but they are longer and bigger. They are eated on the ides and near the bottom of the two Bodies of the Matrix, and the right is higher than the left, as 'tis in Males. Their Subtance and colour alo are very like them. The right is about one inch and an half long, and two lines and an half large; the left is omething les. They have their Epididymis, and their Spermatique veels, that convey the eed into the two Bodies of the Matrix, and which are much horter than thoe of the Males. Yet I oberve, that thee Teticles appear not always uch in all Females, epecially in thoe that are emaciated, either by icknes, or by long keeping; for, their Teticles horten, treighten, and dry, like as in thoe, whoe Eggs are already great; having oberv'd, that in thee the Teticles are much hortned and dryed up, as alo that they are decended lower,
although the right be alwayes found higher than the left.

The Matrix begins in a body pretty thick, which is compos'd of two trong tunicles, and which being eated above the intetin, hath in the ame place its orifice, which is large, and doth eaily dilate, to receive at one and the ame time, by the ame aperture, the two Penes's of the Male, in the Copulation. This Body is about the bignes of a nail of a middleized finger, and is divided very near its beginning into two mall baggs open at the bottom, and fram'd by Nature to receive and embrace the two members of the Male in the coit. Their interiour coat is full of rugoities, and very hard, as is that of the whole body, which we have poken of; o that he uffers, and alo feels pleaure from, the pricking of the little tings of the Male's members, without being hurt thereby, although their points be very harp.

The Matrix begins by thee two little acks or baggs to be divided into two bodies, which acend each on its ide along the kidneys, and betwixt them and the intetins, as farr as to the bottom of the
Stomach, where they are upended by ligaments, which come from about the Liver, being alo utained, from pace to pace, by divers mall ligaments, that come from the Back-bone. Thee two bodies are compoed of two tunicles, that are oft, thin, and tranparent, being one within th' other, Their beginning is at the bottom of thoe two mall bags, which embrace the two members of the male, from whence they receive the eed each from its ide, to breed Eggs of it, and o young Vipers, by the conjunction of their own eed, which the teticles end thither.

Thee two Bodies of the Matrix do very eaily dilate themelves, that they may contain many young Vipers, unto the time of their perfection: notwithtanding the opinion of ome, who have affirm'd, that the Matrix of a Viper had but one onely body; that it was eated in the midle, and all along the Back-bone, and that there were in it ditinct Bodies to hold the Eggs, and the young Vipers, which bodies were dependants of this Matrix. But, I believe, that the ground of their mitake hath been, in that thoe true bodies of the matrix being very delicat and very tranparent, epecially
when they are well'd and ditended by the Eggs, or the Vipers, by them contained, have not paed in their opinion for true bodies of the Matrix, and that they have taken for it the intetins, which are eated in the middle, and appear pretty bigg and thick, and eem to make but one and the ame body with the firt thick body of the matrix, under which the beginning of the firt intetin is fatned and eated.

The Viper is not the onely animal, that hath her matrix divided into two like Bodies, equally placed each on its ide, and along the Guts, which eparate them; for I have oberv'd the ame thing in many Snakes, which I have open'd purpoely to know the truth hereof.

div.head: SECT. 3.
Of the Generation and Production of young Vipers.
div.p:
BY the particular decription, we have made of the parts erving the Viper for generation, is is eay to renounce all the Fables we finde in Books, concerning the copulation of Vipers, and the production of the young Vipers: o that I hall not trouble the Reader any further with them, but onely intimate, That by the means of the inertion of both members of the Male into the two baggs of the Matrix; by the ejaculation of the Seed, made of them both together, into the two bodies of the aid Matrix, which are united at the bottom of the baggs; and by the concurrence of the Femals own eed which her teticles emit at the time of the coit; the Eggs are firt formed in both the bodies of the Matrix: that each is covered by its little tunicle; that the Eggs of each body of the Matrix are altogether wrapped up in one common membrane, commonly
called the Ovarium; that all is incloed in its proper body, the Matrix; that the Eggs there take their increae; that the young Vipers are there formed and perfected; that thence they come forth one after another by the ame paage, where the eed of the Male went in; and that they are produc'd alive, as many other animals, without any need of the intervention of the dam's death.

We can aure the truth of all thee particulars, having verified them by an accurate examination of all the parts, at everal times, and upon a great number of ubjects; and having een the extenion and welling of thoe two bodies of the Matrix, even at the time when the young Vipers were perfected and ready to come forth; and latly having een the paage free, by which they were to come abroad, and the young ones actually produced without any danger to the Dam.

We have noted, that the right body of the Matrix of the Viper is ordinarily fuller of Eggs and young brood, than the left; that the number of Eggs is pretty unequal; that at times there are twenty or twenty five, ometimes but half o many; that the
young Vipers take their form and perfection in the Egg; that there they are eated and entangled divers wayes, and after a very pleaant manner; that they have each within their Egg a kind of after-birth depending from their Navil, by which they draw their food; that in coming abroad they train it after them, and in part are encompaed with it; and that their Dam frees them thereof, and cleaneth them by licking them when they are born.

But although we have, as exactly as we could, decribed all the inward and outward parts of a Viper, both of a Male and Female; yet to the end that all may be the better undertood, we hall addres the Reader to the following Schemes, wherin he may ee the ame parts, we have jut now decribed, repreented and drawn to the life, together with their explication in the Tables accompanying them; hoping, that he will there find atisfaction.

The Reader is deired to take notice, that, having on the Frontipice of this Book repreented two Vipers, a Male and a Female, conjoyned tempore coitts, and there being in the exteriour part of their Body no coniderable difference in the one from the other, but in their Tayle, of which the repreentation may be een eparately in the econd Figure; I thought it needles, to exhibit the whole Figure of a Male by it elf; and have contented my elf to have engraven the Female in the tate he is at the time when he produceth her young ones, which is that, which eem'd to me the mot coniderable for her exteriour Figure.

He will alo find no fault with the Situation, in which the Viper is repreented in the Cutt, at the time when her young ones come forth, ince that beides the Symmetry, which hath been there indutriouly oberv'd, it was alo intended to hew therein the parts, that eem'd very neceary to me, and that could not be repreented elewhere.

div.head: CHAPT. I.
The Biting of a Viper, hapned to a Man.
div.p:
IN the Month of June of the year 1668, I procured a great number of live Vipers, Males and Females, to put the deign in execution, I had purpoed to my elf; Which was, to know in truth all the good and all the evil, a Viper was capable of. I was happy enough in exciting the Curioity of many intelligent Perons, and amongt others, of ome
Phyitians of my acquaintance, very knowing and agacious, who were pleaed to take the pains of coming to my houe every day, to ait in thee experiments, and to impart to me their directions.

The firt Meeting of all proved a ad one by a urpriing mis-fortune. A certain Forrainer, drawn to ee our Experiments by his own curioity, felt in his own peron, contrary to his expectation, a great part of the grievous accidents, which may be caued by Vipers, and furniht us, ore againt our wills, with an Experiment, which was followed with circumtances too coniderable to be uppreed; and I thought my elf obliged to recite them firt of all, becaue it was not onely the firt, but the onely, that hath furniht us with more remarkable things, than all the ret.

This Gentleman, of 25 years of age, had been by chance the day before at my houe, when five or ix douzen of Vipers were brought thither. He would needs ee them immediately, and I, being deirous to atisfie his Curioity, drew out of the Veel one of the Vipers. He was not contented to ee her, but took her in his
hand, and kept her there for about a great quarter of an hour, uffering her to turn and winde herelf about his hand and arm, the Viper not o much as offering to bite him. Then he tyed her about her neck, and o having hanged her, pulled off her skin, and emptied her of her Guts to examine them. I am aured, that he would have been oundly bitten at that time, if the Viper had been vexed; but not having been o, and being pleaed to breath another air than that of the Veel, where he had been long hut in, he let herelf be tyed, after which he could not do that michief, which certainly he would have done, if he had not been tyed.

But this proved quite otherwie the next day; for this tranger being come again to my houe at the hour of the Aembly, he aw one of the Vipers upon the Table, which had been held a long while between Pincers, and was much angred. He would take her with his naked hand, though he was earnetly warn'd to forbear, it being repreented to him, that he had been too bold already the day before. He had no ooner taken her in his hand, but he turn'd her head to bite him, and with one of her
great bent teeth, he laid hold on the lateral inward part of his right thumbe, a little above the ituation of the nail. The pricking appear'd no more than that of a pin; and it eem'd to us not deep, and on the urface we only aw a very mall hole with a very little rednes; o that it was not dicernable but by its colour. There was not upon, nor about this litle hole, any ign of that yellow liquor contain'd in the baggs about the great teeth, and which is wont to be hed upon the wound, when a Viper biteth deep; yet the pricking caued ome pain to him at the very firt, but the finger well'd not of it, no intumecence appearing but ome hours after, as we hall relate more amply in the equel.

It was found proper to carify the part wounded, and to make trong ligatures above the place bitten, both to top the effects of the Venom, and to dicharge the wounded part of the ame; but the Patient oppoed thee means, not believing them neceary; and he could very hardly be perwaded to endure any carification; after which, he endured alo an iron patule very hot and heated over and over again, held very near to the prick't
place; which was done, to keep the pores open, and to fetch back and draw out ome part of the poyon: Mean while, we made the Patient take two drachms of Theriaque in half a glas of Wine.

In les then half a quarter of an hour after the pricking, the patient felt ome debility, and call'd for a chair; he wax'd at the ame time very pale, and his pule was found very low, very quick, and even interrupted. Thee accidents were followed by convulive motions, and by a tifnes of his whole body, and chiefly of his neck, and the mucles of his head: he then alo complain'd of a very great pain towards his Navil; and there appear'd a coldnes in his extreme parts, and in the whole face, which was covered with little drops of cold weat: his lips alo were well'd, epecially the lower. And finding himelf urged by the pains about his Navil, and a dipoition to go to tool, he roe, and having voided ome excrements, he vanih't away, and at the ame time vomited not only all the Theriaque he had taken, but all he had eaten at dinner, which was yet un-digeted. We made hate to uccour him, and found him o feeble,
that he was not able to goe up again to the chamber, whence he was come down. And in regard his pule continued weak, low, quick, and unequal, and his woundings frequent, as well as his cold weats, it was thought eaonable to give him a drachm of Viper-powder in Theriacal and Carduus Benedictus water, and to apply to him a great Plaiter of Theriaque upon the Heart and Stomach, but he oon rejected what he had taken. One alo came to give him ome of the Orvietan, mixt with new powder of Vipers, but he vomited up that alo, and deired to be put upon a bed, and to have other help adminitred to him. During all which time, he neither wanted his enes, nor the ue of reaon, notwithtanding all the feeblenes of his Body; and he had had great averion to the Orvietan, having no faith at all in it, and not conenting to take it, but out of repect to ome of thoe that were preent, who had preed it upon him.

This vomiting not giving time to the remedies to convey and communicate their vertue to the noble parts, it was judged very proper to have recoure to the Volatile
Salt of Vipers, becaue that being very volatile and exceeding fit to be quickly conveyed to all the parts, even the mot remote, the Patient might thence feel the effects with more peed and efficacy, than from all the other groer remedies, which having been rejected as oon as they were taken, had not had time to be made effectual by the tomach, nor to impart their vertue where need required.

We therefore caued to be diolv'd a drachm of this volatile Salt of Vipers in Theriacal and Carduus water, and gave him about a quart of this mixture; he kept it a little while, and then cat up a part of it, mingled with tore of phlegme very vicous. We made him take another like quantity of the ame mixture, which he alo kept for ome time, and then vomited up, what might have remain'd of it in his Stomach, and amongt it much phlegm. We continued to give him till more of the ame compoition as fat as he vomited it up; and there were alo given him everal Clyters, to appeae the violent and tubborn pains, which he felt about his Navil.

His lips remained till wolne, his pule
naught, and his weat cold, as well as his faintings continued very long; but having perited in the ue of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, his vomiting ceaed, and he kept the eighth doe in his belly, which was given him about four hours after he received the michief: the ymptoms leen'd from that time, the cold began little by little to retire, and gave place to the natural heat, which appeared ufficiently about five hours after the pricking; his pule returned, and was even and trong, but omewhat high.

It was about ten of the clock at night, that the mot troubleome accidents diappear'd, the Patient was happy in his unhappines, in being peedily and rationally uccour'd. I left him not, before his mortal accidents had ceaed; and then he was carried to his lodgings, whether I accompanied him, and he was put to bed; and by the advice of thoe perons, that frequently viited him during his ditemper, I made a mixture of one drachm of Confection of Hyacinthe, and of as much of the Confection of Alkermes, and of one ounce of Syrup of Limons, and of four ounces of Carduus-water, which was giv'n
him at three times, from three hours to three hours. There were given him Citrons to mell to, and from time to time ome lices of them ugred. He took good broths, and drank ptian made with Scorzonera-roots, and the havings of Hartshorn, mingled with Syrup of Limons, he alo drank ometimes a little wine, and there was diolved of the Confection of Alkermes, ometimes in his broth, ometimes in his ptiane.

This is a thing remarkable enough, that during all the great accidents, his finger was not changed, and there appeared not any welling upon it, but that began, when thoe accidents ceaed. In the mean time, the pains about the navil continued, though they were in ome little degree abated; which obliged the Phyitians often to precribe him Clyters. His belly was a little tiff, but not welled; his tongue was whitih, but not dry; his eyes faint and wan; his countenance pale, and his lips till welled.

The welling of the finger extended it elf that night over the whole hand; which was often anointed with the Oyl of Scorpions, compoed by Matthiolus, and mixt
with the Queen of Hungarie's water, but, notwithtanding this anointing, the tumor pa'd onto the arm the next day, with pain and rednes, and advanced to the Eye. It was thought fit to apply fomentations made with the roots of Angelica, Imperatoria, Carlina, and Aritolochia, and with the tops of Scordium, Centaurium, Wormwood, St. Johns wort, Calamint, boyled in White wine, and withal to continue the anointing with the aid Oyle of Scorpions among thee fomentations. Although this was done with great care, yet there appeared no great effect upon it; the Patient was queamih, and once vomited up even his broth; but this vomiting continued not. He alwayes ued the ame internal and external remedies, and the ame food; but although he found his other limbs in a good condition, and his pule very equal and moderate, nor had any drought, heat, or pain in the ret of his body, yet was that of the Navil obtinate; and the welling and the rednes of the hand and arm till increaed; and from the beginning of the third day, it had eied on the houlder of the ame ide, and decended to the armpit, upon the whole breat, and all the neighbouring
parts, and even the whole region of the Liver, notwithtanding the continual ue of the fomentations, and the Oyle of Scorpions.

All thee coniderations, joyned to the hot eaon, wherein we were, made us apprehend, let the gangrene hould trike to thoe parts. It was believed, that, ince the outward remedies which had been judged mot expedient, had proved uccesles, recoure mut be had to internal ones; which induced the Phyitians to give him, in the evening of the third day, a drachm of the root of Contra-yerva in powder, diolv'd in cordial waters, with as much confection of Alkermes: but we aw no abatement of the rednes, welling, or pain; on the contrary, we oberv'd, that the welling eem'd to eize on the left ide.

After we had well examin'd all things, we found it very neceary to return to the ue of our firt inward remedy, which had truck the great troke, and had had a manifet good operation; I mean, the Volatil Salt of Vipers. This was in the morning of the fourth day after the biting. So we gave him half a drachm of that Salt, diolved in four ounces of Carduus water, and
we order'd that he hould be well covered, to make him weat. This medicine did work according to our expectation and deire; for the Patient not onely did weat abundantly, but found a very coniderable amendment in all the ill Symptoms that had remain'd. His pain about the navil was almot not enible; the tumor of his Lips, and that, which was in the region of the Liver, Breat, and under the Armpits, vanih't, and that of the houlder, Arm and Hand was much abated, as well as the rednes and pain.

We thence judg'd, that we hould certainly cure the ret; and to compas it, we gave the next morning to our Patient a like doe of that Volatil Salt of Vipers, which made him weat again very largely; the pain of the Navil ceaed altogether; the welling of the houlder was wholly gone; and that of the whole arm and hand was yet much more abated, as well as the rednes and pain. And not to leave the cure imperfect, though the patient found himelf exceedingly amended, we gave him the next day another uch doe again, and the day following one more, whereby the whole welling, all the rednes, and all the
pain of the arm, hand, and the finger itelf, were diipated; Mean while there was applyed to the finger a little plaiter to cicatrize the inciions, that had been made there, and which were healed three or four dayes after. Which did not hinder the Patient to goe abroad, and to doe his buines, as well as if he had never been bitten by the Viper.

Thoe that hall read this Hitory, and examine all the circumtances of it, the everal and urpriing accidents of the biting of the Viper, which we aw, and the effectual operation of the remedies, employed to remove them, will therein find ample matter to exercie their reaoning upon, and will oon judge, that we had caue, accurately to inquire, as we have done, into all the parts of a Viper, to know them well, and what they can doe; to make a great number of Experiments upon all its parts, and to apply ourelves to the preparation of the excellent remedies, that may be drawn from the body of this Animal.

The Extraordinary effect of its Volatil Salt, in topping and in overcoming, firt of all the Venome, which o violently exercied
