its tyranny over the natural heat, and all the noble parts, and which doubtles would have altogether triumphed over them: the activity, penetration, and force of the ame Salt, going to find out the poyon, and expelling it from the remotet parts of the body, where it had fortified itelf, and whence it endeavoured to regain the place it had lot, and where, in the mean time, it eem'd to depie the ordinary mot powerful remedies. All this, I ay, is ufficient to make it to be wondred at; and men will, doubtles, averr, that the ill, which Vipers are able to caue, and which every one may eaily avoide, is nothing in comparion of uch a remedy, as the ame Vipers can furnih, and which may erve, not onely to heal their bitings, but alo to overcome many other obtinate dieaes, againt which the ordinary remedies perform nothing; not to peak of many other good preparations, made of Vipers, which we intend to decribe hereafter.

div.head: EXPERIMENTS Of the Biting of Vipers, upon other Animals.
CHAPT. II.
Experiments upon Dogs.
div.p:
THE effects, that are urpriing, are wont enibly to touch the Minds of Men; and they are they, which excite the Curious to inquire into the Caue of them; and although this do alwayes precede thoe, yet it would not be known, and we hould not o much as be aware that it was, if the effects thereof did not firt appear. Being therefore to treat of the Biting of Vipers, we hope, it will not be thought amis, if we begin with the recitation of the Experiments, by the Examples of its effects. And not
to be tedious to the Reader; having reviewed all that hath been experimented at my houe, both the lat and this year, I hall confine my elf to what I think deerves mot to be communicated, what erveth mot to our purpoe, and what may give mot atisfaction to the Curious.

One of the mot coniderable Experiments was made on a Dog, which was bitten by an angred Viper at the upper lipp. The dog was not much moved at it at firt, but little by little grew ad, and his jaw began to well: a little while after he vomited up the lat food he had taken, and dunged. Then ome bread, fleh, and water being offred him, he would touch none of it, he remain'd in a protrate poture without complaining, the place of the pricking waxed livid, and this lividnes extended it elf to the neck, and as far as the breat, as did alo the welling. At length he dyed, but not till fourty hours were pat after the biting. His belly appear'd not woln, and without we oberv'd nothing extraordinary but the tumour and lividnes in the part prick't, and thereabout. The Dog being opened after his death, we found in the tronc of
the vena cava a little bloud curdled, and we noted, that the ret of the bloud, in this place, in the heart, and every where ele, was of a dark colour, and of a very ill conitence, as if it were blood in part diolv'd and corrupted. The Stomach appear'd of a darkih colour, but the Meentery and the Gutts were darker. We found no alteration in the Heart, Liver, Lungs, nor the Spleen; all thee parts being of a very fine colour, and in their natural condition.

div.head: The Biting of a Dog at the Ear.
div.p:
THis Dog howled from the time he felt the biting, and continued his howling for half an hour; then he ceaed to howl and to complain. The place prick't wax'd livid, and well'd, as alo did the Neighbouring parts. This dog vomited not, but voided ome excrements, which eemed natural. He would neither eat nor drink, no more then the firt, and he oon dyed, having liv'd no longer then twenty four hours after he
had been bitten. We aw outwardly nothing un-common, but the lividnes and welling at the neighbouring part, and thereabout. But having opened him, we found all the inward parts in the ame condition with thoe of the former dog. 'Tis true, we did not finde in this dog any coagulated blood, neither in the heart, nor the vena cava, nor ele where, but it was of an obcure colour, and of an odd conitence, and in a viible dipoition to coagulate.

div.head: Another biting of a Dog.
div.p:
WE had a Dog bitten by an irritated Viper at the tip of his Noe, the dog howled, when he felt himelf bitten, but was oon appeaed, falling to lick the place prick't, and to cratch it with his paws. He lay not down, but continued for ome time in that exercie, and went up and down in the chamber. The place bitten became omewhat black and blew, but well'd not; and a little while after the dog drank and eat, as if he had never
been bitten: The lividnes diappeared little by little, and the Dog was as well as ever.

div.head: The Biting of a little dog.
div.p: A Yong Puppy, but 7. or 8. dayes old, was bitten in the leg by an enraged Viper; the dog began to howl as oon as he was bitten, and o continued till he dyed, which he did one hour after. The part pricked was welled and livid, as in the former, and the animal being open'd, we found nothing extraordinary in his body, ave onely ome lividnes in the Stomach and Gutts, and ome blackihnes and ill conitence in the bloud, as in the others; for all the other inward parts appear'd to us very ound.

div.head: Another biting of a Dog.
div.p:
WE caued alo another Dog to be bitten under the Belly by another
angred Viper. He howled preently, but that lated not long. The place bitten welled much, and was very livid, and the tumor and lividnes reached over all the natural parts. This Dog drank often, but would eat nothing, and was alwayes in this condition without growing wore. Two dayes after, to be more certain of the thing, we caued him to be bitten again, and that twice, near the ame place, where he had been bitten at firt. He again howled much, and the welling increas'd, and extended it elf over the whole belly, as well as the black and blew colour; but it went no further; for the dog often licked his wounds, and drank tore of water, and at lat fell to eat, o that without any other remedy, but his tongue, all the welling and blew colour vanih't in five or ix daies. And the dog was in the ame condition, he had been in before he was wounded.

div.head: Another Dog bitten in the Tongue.
div.p:
THis Dog gave us ome trouble; for he defended himelf a great while,
before he would let out his Tongue; but yet at lat he received therein a deep bite by an enraged Viper. At firt he howled extremely, o as to be heard afar off, and o continued, toing and tormenting himelf for half an hour together, and then dyed. We opened him alo, and although the Heart, Liver, Lungs, and Spleen were in a very good condition, his tongue was exceedingly livid; his meentery cover'd all over with black pots, ome of which were blacker then lentils, under which there was coagulated blood; the Stomach and Guts were alo blacker than thoe of all the others. The bloud very black, and beginning to coagulate in the heart, and in the vena cava, being alo of the conitence of bloud curdled and corrupted.

This lat Experiment gave us great atisfaction, informing us fully of the effects of the venomous biting of a Viper, and hewing us, that the poyon goes not directly to the noble parts, eeing we never oberv'd any alteration therein, but that 'tis chiefly the bloud it works upon, ince it corrupts the ubtance thereof, coagulateth it, or eparateth its parts, diturbs
its circulation; and at the ame time hinders the communication of the Spirits through the whole body, depriving the noble parts of them, as well as of the pure bloud, which was wont to bedew them, and detroying them indirectly, by cauing this privation of Spirits and of the good liquor, whence depends their ubitence.

We alo found thereby that the progres of the venom of a Vipers biting principally depends from the place bitten, and from the bignes of the veins or arteries, which the teeth hath lighted on. For, the tongue of the Dog being full of veins and arteries, 'tis no wonder, if the Venom, meeting with them, and finding in them a large way, very hort and very free to triumph over the bitten animal, did oon produce its effects, and caued death much more peedily, than that, which met only with mall, lender and winding branches, by which its way was traighter, more about, and longer; though it failed not to do execution at lat; which it would have done ooner, if the paage had been freer.

We may judge by the effects of the venom
of the Vipers biting in thoe dogs, and epecially in the lat, that the vomiting, and the extreme pains about the Navil, which befell the Gentleman, above dicoured of, proceeded partly from the bloud which was coagulated or dipoed to coagulation in its coure, and which could not freely circulate; and partly from this, that the pirits, which accompany the bloud in the circulation, finding obtacles in their paage, endeavoured to make way for themelves, and to that end, doing violence to the lateral parts in their way, caued in thoe places the extreme pains, which the Patient felt there; which might alo be augmented by the bloud, that probably was coagulated out of the great veels, and might be dipered in the form of pots in the Meentery, or elewhere, jut as in the body of the Dog.

We may conclude alo, that the cold weats, the convulions and the faintings, wherewith the Patient was moleted, came from nothing ele, but the defect of the ordinary commerce of the pirits with the noble parts, and from the goodnes and purity of the bloud detinated to bedew them.

Concerning the ucces of the remedies employed to cure the aid Gentleman, we hall declare our thoughts thereof in the equele of our Experiments, after we hall have given proofs ufficient to upport them.

As to the Dogs, that were cured by licking the wound, I think that that was a good means to recall and draw back the venom; and I am much of their opinion, who believe, that if the peron bitten, or ome friend for him, hould for a good while and trongly uck the wound, it would be cur'd, provided that the teeth of the Viper have not lighted upon ome great veel, whereby the progres of the venom may prevail over the force of ucking. I am alo peruaded, that thee ucked and recall'd Spirits are incapable to annoy him who ucks them, partly becaue they have been weakn'd by the action they have been upon, partly becaue they are then detitute of the intruments proper to convey and econd their action, to wit, the teeth of the Viper.

div.head: CHAPT. III.
EXPERIMENTS Of the Biting of Vipers, made upon Pigeons and Pullets.
div.p: THE Experiments made upon thee Animals have likewie been very ueful to us, to know the effects of the Biting of Vipers, which have been very like in both.

We caued a Pigeon and a Pullet to be bitten by a vexed Viper, almot at the ame time, in the mot flehy part, namely in that under the breat. We oon after oberved in both a very thick and extraordinary beating of the heart, which went on till increaing, and in uch a manner, that both Pigeon and Pullet were dead in les then half an hour. We oon opened them, and found in both of them a little bloud coagulated in the heart and the vena cava, and all the ret of the bloud blackih, dipoed to curdle, and as 'twere turn'd and
corrupt; but the Heart, and Liver, and all the inward and outward parts of a very good colour, and in a very good condition, ave that a little lividnes appear'd upon the place bitten.

We have frequently oberv'd the ame thing in many Pullets and Pigeons: But it will not be amis, here to relate the different ucces in two Pigeons, we caued to be bitten equally and in the ame place by an angred Viper. One of them we made to wallow the weight of about half a crown of Theriack, a moment before it was bitten, giving nothing to the other. The former being bitten, went to and fro in the room, o as not to hew any ign of illnes, but the latter was dead in les than a quarter of an hour We afterwards caued the former to be bitten again in the leg; and then it grew ick by little and little, and dyed half an hour after. We found the place of the firt pricking much more livid, then that of the Pigeon, which dyed in a quarter of an hour; and even more then the place of the leg, which was bitten afterward. We judged, that the vexed pirits unable to penetrate into the body, defended by the Theriaque, had
wrought upon the outward part, and round about the place bitten, where they had coagulated the bloud, and caued the lividnes; whereas the like pirits, having met with no reitance in the other Pigeon, had gained and wrought upon the inner parts, having left and as 'twere depied the place, at which they were entred. We alo wondred not, that the Theriaque, which had vigorouly repuled the Spirits introduc'd by the firt bite, could not reit the latter but for half an hour, and that at lat it was forced to yield, in regard that the number of the enemies was great, and being weakn'd by the conflict, it had but now endured, had not force enough to bear up againt the new aault of the latter.

We did alo prick everal times, and pretty deep, dogs, pigeons and pullets, with the long teeth of Vipers, ome pull'd out of the throat of dead ones, others out of uch as were alive. There was alo one of the company, who handling a dead vipers head, had a mind to prick his finger, and actually did o, with one of the great teeth, o that the bloud iued. I alo my elf thrut into my hand one of them, and o deep, that a piece of it remain'd more
than half an hour in my fleh; but in all this we found not the leat appearance of venom, nor any ill, but uch, as might be caued by the pricking of a Pin, or ome uch thing.

We alo deplum'd a Pigeon at the mot flehy place, and holding with both our hands the jawes of a Viper open, and making her raie her great teeth, we preed both the jawes at once againt that flehy part, and caued the teeth deeply to enter into it, and order'd the matter o, that the yellow liquor of the Gums had time enough to pas into the wounds, which the teeth had made. We at the ame time aw, that the bloud iued out of the wounds, and mingled it elf with the yellow juyce, which remained there. We had then ready a little tone, come from Portugal, which thoe of that Country call the Snake-Stone, being pretty black, hining, roundih, and flat, about the bignes of a French piece of five Sols, but three times thicker; which we preently applyed to the place bitten, which was cover'd with bloud, and with the yellow liquor mingled therewith. The tone immediately was fatned to the wound, and we perceived nothing,
extraordinary in the Pigeon. We might have believed, that this afety of the Pigeon was due to the vertue of this Stone, which they would aure us was infallible againt the bitings of Vipers and all kinds of Serpents, if we had not ome dayes before tryed the like Stone upon a Pigeon, bitten in the ame place by an angry Viper, and if that wound had not been follow'd by the death of that Pigeon, a quarter of an hour after. We thought, this very well deerved another experiment; and having till the ame Stone by us, which eem'd to have aved the former pigeon, and uch another, which the Lord Ambaadour of Spain had truted his Phyitian with, we by one and the ame enraged Viper caued to be bitten two Pigeons of equal bignes and flehines, each in the ame place, well freed from its feathers. The bloud was een upon both wounds; but there appear'd but little of the yellow liquor. We oon applyed both the Stones, one to each Pigeon; they preently tuck fat to the places pricked; but we aw immediately in both a very high and thick beating of the heart, which was follow'd by the death of both Pigeons, which hapned
at one and the ame time, in les than a quarter of an hour.

We had alo a mind to know, whether the Venom, that had o much force upon the bloud, were alo able to make ome ill impreion upon the noble or olid parts of the bitten animals, which parts appear'd to us very fair and very well conditioned. We gave alo a Pigeon, dead of a Vipers biting, to be eaten by a Cat that was very lean, which fed very greedily upon it; and the ame did afterwards eat many more, and Pullets alo; upon which he grew very fat, o far was he from finding any inconvenience thereby.

Moreover we had a deire to learn, whether one and the ame Viper was able to kill by its biting divers animals wounded, one preently after another; and whether the Venom was exhautible, o that the animals, bitten lat, might be free from its michievounes. To know the truth hereof, we caued to be bitten five Pigeons one after another, by the ame Viper, which we angred every time he was to bite: All thee Pigeons oon dyed; and we particularly oberved, that the lat bitten dyed firt of all. And as to the Bloud,
and all the inward and outward parts, they were in a manner alike with thoe of the Pigeon, that was bitten firt.

The various Experiments, we have been relating, do inenibly oblige us to deliver our thoughts concerning the Venom of Vipers, and its operation. We think this to be a proper place to declare ourelves here, and afterwards to employ the ret of our main experiments for the defence of what we hall have advanced upon this Subject.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Venom of a Vipers Biting, and its Operation.
div.p:
THE Antiens, prevented by the opinion, that there were very few parts in a Viper, that were exempt of poyon, have but very lightly examin'd them. And as they eteemed that the Choller of the Viper did much contribute
to the Venom, believing, that the eat thereof was in the Gall, they there alo etled that of the poyon, and imagined, that the tate of the Gall, very harp and very bitter, was an argument of its malignity, and that the veins and arteries, which pas near the Gall, and may be followed as far as into the jawes, and appear the ame through the whole body, above and below the Gall, were the pipes, which Nature had purpoely form'd to carry the juyce of the Gall into the Gums, and that it was that liquor, which caued all the mortal Symptoms, and death it elf.

But they have not conidered, that this Choler of the Viper reideth not in the Gall; that the Galls of innumerable other Animals have a tate very approaching to that of a Viper, and yet are not venomous; that the veins and arteries, which pas near the Gall, and eem to part thence and extend unto the Gumms, and all the parts of the Body, are veels deigned, onely to convey the blood, which have not their origin in the Gall, and which cannot carry a juyce, which they could not receive: that there is not any
tate of Gall in all thoe imagined Veels, no more than there is in the liquor of the Gums, nor in all the ret of the Body above the Gall: and that in the whole Bladder of Gall there is but one veel, that is any thing coniderable, though it be very lender, which iuing, as we have aid, from the internal ide of the upper part of the Gall, decends (o far is it from acending) and dicharges it elf into the firt intetine, according to the decription we have made of it, and conformably to the Figure, that may be een in the Cut.

But not to tay upon principles o lightly etablih't, and ill maintain'd, foramuch as we have on our ide a great number of Experiments, upon which we are grounded; We ay, That the Gall of a Viper is not at all Venomous, but that on the contrary it contains a Vertue, that is Balamick and cleaning, and very proper for many good ues; that there is no Veel, which carries its juyce to the Veicles, that are about the great teeth; that the yellow liquor, therein contain'd, is in all things very different from that of the Gall, excepting that they are both equally free from Venom; that that yellow liquor is gather'd,
and form'd by the Salival Glands, above decribed; that it is carried into thoe Veicles or Baggs by the Lymphatick veels which part from thoe Glands; that this juyce is nothing but a pure and plain Saliva, of which we have already obervd the ue; and that this juyce contributes nothing to the venomounes of the Biting; ince, being tated and wallowed (as we have often experimented) it does no hurt neither to man nor beat; and ince alo, being put upon open wounds, and upon inciions made in the fleh, the ame being rubb'd therewith, and mingled with the bloud, it annoyes nothing at all: notwithtanding the judgment of a peron very intelligent, and particularly in this ubject of Vipers, wo aures to have made a great number of Experiments; which being contrary to ours, the great opinion we have of the abilities and the incerity of that famous man, hath obliged us to employ the more care and exactnes, and to confirm ourelves, by a very great number of Experiments, which have alwayes been found alike, in the truth, we here aert, and of which we hall make evident and irrefragable proof.

We ay further, that there is no other venom in all the other parts of the Body; and more, that there is none even in the great teeth, if the Viper be not alive, and the biting not accompanied with vexed and enraged Spirits. The hurt, which the teeth doth, when the Viper biteth, conits chiefly in that it opens a door to the angred Spirits, without which irritation the Biting of the teeth is not mortal, and ought to be no further conider'd then for the deep and direct wound, which a tooth, o harp, o long, and o lender, of any other animal whatoever, might make. In which circumtances, the great number of Experiments, by us made, hath rendred us knowing; in regard that we have oberved a quite manifet difference in the Biting of a Viper angred, from that of a Viper, which was made to bite by holding its jaws, and by preing its great teeth into the body of ome animal: becaue this forc'd action erves rather to make the Viper retain its pirits, then to let them out; for which the freedom of the animal is neceary, the pirits not being able to part, but the imagination and the Choler of the Viper
mut immediately precede and thrut them out. For this way of biting, by holding the jaws, and thruting the teeth into ome animal, although it emit more of the yellow liquor upon the part bitten, than the biting made by an angred Viper, left to it elf, is not followed by any initer accident, and is healed like a imple wound, whereas the other is attended with death, in cae we want means of preventing it.

The effect therefore of the venom being altogether of a pirituous nature, and not working but according as the pirits are more or les iritated and puh't on, and according as they finde more or les free paage, we have reaon to impute it to the exaperated Spirits, having found no foottep of it, neither real, nor apparent in all the viible parts. But the better to maintain this our aertion, we hall here give you our thoughts concerning the action of the enraged Spirits.

Thee Spirits then, puh't on by the choler, which the Viper had conceived, finding the apertures, made by the Teeth, follow their inclination, and as it is their property, to advance and penetrate, they at the firt eek out all wayes for it, and
they advance more or les, according to the facility or difficulty, they meet with. Thence it is, that the Biting is much more dangerous, when the teeth light upon the greater veels, than when they only light upon Fleh, or the little branches of the veins and Arteries. So that the vexed Spirits of a Viper, meeting with the bloud and Spirits contain'd in the veels of the bitten animal, puh and pres them to make way for themelves, and embaraing the particles that compoe the bloud, caue there a coagulation or confuion, which diturbs the ordinary Circulation, and by this means hinders the communication of the Spirits, to the principal parts, from which depends their ubitence and life. And by reaon of this privation they mut uccumbe, either for having been attack't in their fort by thee vexed Spirits and infected by them, or rather becaue thee pirits of the Viper have made themelves maters of the avenues, and obtructed the paages, by which the blood and the pirits were communicated to them.

We conclude therefore, that the imagination of the Viper being irritated by
the idea of revenge which he had fram'd to her elf, gives a certain motion to the Spirits which cannot be expreed, and puhes them violently, through the nerves and their fibres, towards the cavity of the teeth, as into a funnel; and that from htence they are convey'd into the blood of the animal, by the opening, which they have made, there to produce all thoe effects, of which we end eavour to give a reaon. Others, more able than we, may perhaps carry their reaoning farther.

For the ret, ome have thought, that thoe enraged Spirits have in them a ecret acidity, capable to coagulate the bloud, and to hinder the Circulation, whence the mortall accidents proceed. But ince that this acidity may have been produced in the mas of the Blood by its own parts, which come to be diolved and evered, when they are tainted by the venom, and ince corruption lides into it, as into milk, which owreth and corrupteth of it elf, without mixing any acid thing therewith; it is not neceary to earch for a coagulating Acid in the Spirits of the Viper, which cannot be perceived by the tate to know the truth of its exitence therein;
and that the les, becaue that Acid may be naturally formed in the Bloud of the animal bitten, without looking for it in the Viper, as if it had come from thence.

How-ever this be, we mut agree herein, that this irritation in the phany or in the pirits of the Viper is the main caue of the activity and piercingnes of its venom, and that without it the biting would not produce uch urpriing effects, as thoe are, of which we have related o many Examples. Nor is a viper the onely animal, whoe biting is mortal: Dogs, Wolves, and Men themelves prove that; and not to go from our Subject, the biting of Serpents, of which the Viper is a pecies, is more or les malign, according to the nature of their pirits, and epecially according as they are angred and exaperated.

It eems, that Cleopatra was well intructed in this matter, when he, intending to kill herelf, commanded to be brought her two Apes in a fruit-basket, and pricked them with a golden needle, which he pulled out of her hair-dres, and made her elf be bitten immediately by one of thoe Apes in the right arm, and by the other,
in her left breat; knowing (as a famous Author aith) that their natural fiercenes and cruelty was not ufficient to execute well what he deired, and that it was needful, this pricking hould erve to provoke the pirits to bite to purpoe, and to render the wound mortal; if at leat it be with their biting, as it is with that of our Vipers, who alo have this particular quality, that not onely they are oon angred, but that in the very moment of the irritation they bite with a trange wiftnes; which peaketh much the ubtlety and impetuounes of their pirits, whence depends their trength and activity. We oberve alo, that in ditilling Vipers bodies, we thence draw very ubtile and very penetrating parts, and in much greater quantity, in proportion, than from any other animal.

In the mean time, the obtacle, which thee irritated pirits of the Viper give to the communication of the pirits of the animal bitten, nor the coagulation, or confuion, which they caue to the bloud, are not of that force, that pecifique remedies hould not mater them, and retore the animal unto that Condition,
wherein it was before it was wounded. Which is that, we hall prove in the equele by divers Experiments; where we hope to hew in what manner the remedies do overcome the powerful action of thoe enraged Spirits.

div.head: CHAP. V.
EXPERIMENTS Of the yellow juyce, contain'd in the Veicles of the great teeth, made upon divers Animals.
div.p:
IN the deign, we had, well to try all things, we purued our Experiments, and to be well aured of the quality of that yellow liquor, which hath been believed o dangerous, we caued to be bitten, by ix angred Vipers, eparately
and everal times by each of them, a lice of bread, and o much, that it had well exhauted and retain'd all the yellow liquor, contained in the Gums of thee ix Vipers: At the ame time we gave this lice of bread to a fating Dog, to eat, who was no more inconvenienced thereby, than if he had eaten a piece of dry bread, that had imbibed nothing of this juyce.
We have alo often made divers Pullets and Pigeons to wallow pieces of bread dipped in the ame liquor; and we can aure, that none of thee animals had any michief thereupon.

I my elf had the curioity to tate of this juyce, which I have divers times done in the preence of many perons, without wahing my mouth before or after. And everal Phyitians alo have tated of it themelves, both to know the tat, and to be aur'd of the harmlesnes thereof; and 'tis certain, that they were no more incommoded thereby than myelf.

And becaue it hath been believed, that this juyce, being thus tated and wallowed by Men or other Animals, that had no
wound nor Ulcer in their mouths, nor in their tomachs, was indeed harmles; but that it was quite another thing, when it did accompany a Biting, and entred into the openings made by the teeth and that the ame being put upon an Ulcer, a wound, or a imple excoriation made on the skin, was mortal, and failed not to produce its effect, three or four hours after it had been put upon the wound; and that as well upon Men, as all other orts of Animals, without exception; we reolved alo to make many Experiments upon this account.

I can therefore ay, in the firt place, that I have tated of it my elf, at uch times, when my mouth was excoriated, upon which I oberved, that even my pittle was a little ting'd with bloud, without having perceived any acrimony, or extraordinary heat. We alo made a Tryal upon a Pigeon, which we wounded under the wing, and in the leg in the ame moment of time; and we let into each wound ome of this yellow liquor, which we jut afore had drawn from the gums of two enraged Vipers; then we re-joyned the skin, well to incloe the aid liquor, and we bound both wounds over with a
band, that nothing might run out. We can aure, that the Pigeon felt not any inconveniency from it, and that we even found upon the wound, made on the leg, a coagulated drop of the juyce, round, and of the ame colour, as we had put it there, and the bloud of the place dryed, and that, oon after, both wounds were dryed up, and heal'd of themelves.

We alo made the like Experiment upon a Cat, which we purpoely wounded in the leg, but he received no harm at all by it. We have alo often experimented it upon Pullets, and other Pigeons, but alwayes with the like ucces, and without any offence to the Animals.

The ame tryal hath been thrice made at three everal times, and even twice in one day, upon a dog, whom we had wounded on purpoe towards the bottom of the Ear, where he could not lick his wound; and no michief at all followed upon it.

We cannot but adde here an Experiment of the mortal effect of the enraged Spirits, without any intervention of the yellow liquor We made a Viper everal times to bite upon a lice of bread, by preing every time its jaws againt the bread,
and we did this o often, that not only that juyce was altogether exhauted, but that the bloud began to come out of the gums. At the ame time we vexed the Viper, and made it bite a Pigeon in the mot flehy part; and we oberv'd, that indeed the effects of the venom of the biting were not o quick, the Pigeon not dying but an hour and an half after it had been bitten; but then we found alo, that the teeth of the Viper were in a manner cover'd with the crums of the bread, from the force of its having bitten at it, and that that had hindred them from making a deep entrance, and that having half top'd up the pores of the tooth, a good part of the angred Spirits could not come forth; o that the death of the Pigeon could not follow o fat, though yet it hapned without any mixture of the juyce which had been altogether emptied.

div.head: CHAPT. VI.
EXPERIMENTS Of the Gall, Eggs, Intetins, Head, and Bloud of Vipers, made upon divers Animals.
div.p:
WE have made everal Dogs and Cats to wallow the Galls of Vipers, ometimes whole, ometimes burt, and diolv'd in ome liquor, and ometimes ix, ometimes ten, ometimes a dozen at a time; but they never found themeves ill after it, no more than the Pigeons and Pullets that had wallowed ome of it, and which we had alo wounded, and afterwards rubbed with the Gall of a Viper: for this Gall erved them for a Balom, the wounds being the ooner cured thereby; o that we can jutly declare the
gall to be free from all venom, as well as the yellow liquor, and even inculcate here what we have already aid, that the galls of Vipers have particular vertues in them.

We can ay the ame of the Matrix and Eggs of a Viper, and of all the Intetins, of which we often have made good quantities to be wallowed by Doggs and Cats, ome of which have eaten thereof with greedines, when they could light upon't; and none ever hath felt any trouble after it. On the contrary, we have tryed, that having caued to be bitten, at the thicket place of the Ear, by a ufficiently vexed Viper, a young Cat, very lean, that had but jut before eaten the Eggs, the Matrix, and all the guts of a Viper; the biting had almot no effect, and there appeared nothing but a very little welling, and a very inconiderable lividnes in the place bitten.

We have further made many Dogs and Pigeons wallow the Heads of Vipers, newly cut off, and yet living, having only cut with Sizers the point of their great teeth, leat in paing down they hould bite the throat, or the inward parts of the animals, that were to devour them; but
we have not oberv'd any thing after it, that was extraordinary, in all thoe creatures.

We had alo a deire to find, Whether a Viper, being eaten by an Animal, which it had bitten before, would be cur'd of that biting. We therefore caued to be lightly broyled the head of a Viper, which had on it a part of its neck, newly ever'd from the body; and we made a Dog to be thrice bitten at the Ear by a well enraged Viper, in uch a manner that the bloud came out at the three places pricked. We oon cat before him the head and neck, broyled, and yet hot. The dog, that was hungry, and felt not o oon the effects of the bitings, immediately eized on the head, bruied it between his teeth, and wallowed it down: after which we tayed a pretty while to ee, whether the three bitings would prevail over the devoured head and neck; but the Dog was free, except ome blewnes and a little tumor, he had at the places bitten, but which little by little vanih't in three or four dayes.

We made alo a dog to be bitten three times in the ame place, and without broyling the head of the ame Viper that had
bit him, we cat it to him, hoping that he would eat it, becaue he had not eaten any thing for many hours before; but the dog would not touch it. Upon that we bruied and tamp'd that head in a mortar, and o cramm'd it down the dogs throat; rubbing alo the bitten places with the bloud of the ame Viper: which done, we expected the ucces; which was, that this head, raw and bruied, and if you will, aited by the blood of the Viper, being applyed to the part bitten, had produced the ame effects with the former, which had been o lightly broyl'd; in regard that this dog was free, excepting thoe inconveniences the former uffer'd, and was, after that as ound, as if he had never been bitten.

If thee two Experiments had been made, before that Gentleman, above dicours'd of, was bitten by the Viper, we hould have been in much les anxiety for his preervation. But it was enough, that we were able to ecure him from the dangerous effects of the biting, by wayes grounded upon reaon, and by remedies, that were more proper for uch perons, as could not well reolve to eat the bare fleh of Vipers.

div.head: CHAPT. VII.
Several other Curious Experiments made upon Vipers.
div.p:
WHereas we gave but little credit to what divers Authors have aured to be true, namely, that the Head of a Viper bruied and applyed to the biting of it would heal the ame; we made a Pigeon to be bitten in the mot flehy part of its body, well freed of its feathers, and we cut, bruied, and applyed to the place bitten, the head of the ame Viper, that had wounded the Pigeon, and took care to have it held upon it with a hand. We alo cut the head of a living Viper, and had it lightly broyl'd, then bruis'd and laid hot to the wound of another Pigeon, which had been newly bitten in the ame place, to find, whether by the heat of the
broyling, the parts of the head being more open'd, and the pirits more et at liberty, they would work better; but the ucces was not more beneficial for one Pigeon, than the other; for they both dyed half a quarter of an hour after they had been bitten; and their bodies being open'd, we found in them, what we did in others, kill'd by Vipers, namely a blackih blood, in part coagulated, and half corrupted, in the heart and the great veels; but we took notice, that there was les black & blew about the place bitten; which was perhaps all the effect, that thee bruied heads had produced, which had not been able to carry their virtue any farther.

It is not o, (to ay that on the by) with the pricking of a Scorpion, which being bruied on the part tung, erves for an Antidote, and cureth: for which this reaon may be alledged, that the venom of a Scorpion, not working o briskly, and not piercing with o much quicknes unto the inward parts; the Spirits, that iue from the bruied Scorpion, have leiure to make way for themelves, and to go and find out the venom, to joyn with it, and to make it come forth; whereas the venom
of the Viper goes immediately to taint the mas of the blood, and the parts which it bedeweth; as was apparent in our Gentleman, who had no pains nor welling in his arm, but after all the other accidents; contrary to the operation of the Scorpions Venom, which, before it paeth further, acteth upon the part prick'd by benumming, cold, and tenion, or by inflammation, and very great pains; as thoe Authors, that have written thereof, and the perons, that have been prick'd by them, doe aure.

We have found very true, what Signor Redi hath aid of the effects of the Eence of Tobacco upon Vipers; That, running their skin through with a thred dipp'd in that eence, and leaving the thred in the skin, the Viper dies in les than a quarter of an hour, and becomes as hard as bras, but oon after upple and plyant. We have alo tryed, that a little piece of Tobacco in the roll, held in the throat of a Viper, and the moak of Tobacco blown into its throat produce the like effect, but a little more lowly; and that both do caue convulions, and extraordinary contractions in a viper, which are attended
with death; and that, when all the other parts of the body are deprived of motion, the heart yet beats about half an hour after; and that Tobacco, or its eence, kills Snakes as well as Vipers. I know not, whether this will do with other animals, ince, having run a thred dipt in the eence of Tobacco, into the skin of the under-belly of a Dog, he immediately howled very much, and continued o to do for half a quarter of an hour, running round, then lying down, and then riing again, and in the mean time purging above and below, and voyding excrements more liquid then ordinarily. He would eat nothing, and onely drunk now and then a little, after which he vomited; but this was all the trouble he had, which inenibly went away, and oon after, without any other accident.

We have vexed a viper, and made it to bite another viper, which on purpoe we held within the reach of its teeth. But although he open'd her throat, and put her elf into a poture of biting, yet he refrained, and unk not her teeth deep into the body of the other; which moved us to thrut them our elves by preing her jaws;
but the bitten viper received no inconvenience from it. Yet we have oberved, that a viper which was made to wallow ome of the eence of Tobacco, and which we yet held by the neck with pincers, did bite herelf; but as the eence alone failed not to kill her, o there was no reaon to impute her death to this kind of biting, which was probably an effect of the convulive motions caued by the eence of Tobacco.

We alo pierced twice, in the day-light, with the point of a pen-knife, the head of a live viper in the midt of the Brain, from the top to the botom; one thrut long-wayes, the other cros-wayes, and in uch a manner, that the blood run out both above and below; but notwithtanding, the viper, being let looe, crept about as before, and as if he had not been wounded; but he till lot bloud by the wounds, and at lat dyed at the end of an hour, but her heart did till beat and continue to do o two hours after. Which Experiment ufficiently argues the extraordinary vivacity of the Spirits of the viper.

We have alo put into a glas-veel, a
living viper, together with three live Scorpions, and there left them together four dayes; but found them in the ame condition, in which they were, when we put them in, though there be Authors that aure, that thee Animals kill one another, being hut up together in one and the ame veel. Mean time a viper will kill Scorpions, as well as Lizzards, and other animals to devour them and feed upon them, but that he doth only, when he is at liberty, and not when imprion'd; for then he ceaeth to take food.

We have likewie found the contrary to what Authors have affirm'd of the Wape's attaching a Viper, and that the former would fix its ting into the head of the latter, and quitted her not, till he were dead.

Divers Authors have aur'd, that all the remedies, which are reputed Alexiterial, or Preervatives againt poion, did kill Vipers, by their vertue contrary and oppoite to their venom. To be certain hereof, we forced a Viper to wallow half a drachm of Theriaque, diolved in Carduus Benedictus-water; and having laid her aide, we perceived not any change in her,
except that the urface of her skin appear'd for a while a little moit; but he grew more vivid upon it, and more ready to bite than before.

We had alo a minde to know the effect of Spirit of Wine upon a Viper. We therefore made one wallow about a drachme of it; which thereupon was preently tun'd, and then fell into trange agitations; but eeing that that ceaed little by little, we gave her another doe of the ame quantity, which not onely caus'd in her the like agitation, but afterwards made her almot un-moved, and o inebriated her that he eem'd to be half dead. She remain'd about three hours in this condition, but at length he began to tir again, and was like the former, more brisk, and more dipoed to bite than before. We put alo a living Viper into a bottle almot full of Spirit of wine, and we aw, that he turned to and fro therein, now wimming on the top, then in the middle, and by and by at the bottom of the bottle, and that he reited a good hour, before he was choaked therein.

We caued likewie a Viper to wallow ome ugar, part of which was in powder,
and the other part diolv'd in water. She kept the whole for a while with her, but afterwards vomited it up; and having laid her aide, to ee, what would become of her, we found her dead four and twenty hours after.

We have often pit into the throats of many Vipers, even when we were fating, but they oon after cat up our pitle, and had not any hurt thereby; though there be Authours affirming that Vipers become tabid or conumptive thereby; which yet may very well happen, not from thence, but rather from the abtinence and adnes, after a long imprionment.

Many Authors have mentioned, that Vipers have a great Antipathy to Ahwood, and that, if a live Viper were put within a round, made, one half, of the leaves of Ah, and the other half, of kindled coales, the Viper would rather expoe herelf to be burnt, then to come near the Ah-leaves. But having made a whole round of uch leaves, which had about three foot in diameter, we put a Viper in the midt, which preently hid herelf under thoe leaves.

Whilet I had live Vipers in my houe,
everal Women with child came to me, ome deignedly to ee them, others without having any uch thought, and even being urpris'd at, and abhorring the ight of them; but none of them having been inconvenienced by it; o far were they from micarrying thereupon, as certain Authors would beare us in hand they would do. Not that uch a thing may not chance to happen to ome woman or other extraordinary fearful, and of a temper o delicate, that a much les occaion might produce uch an effect; but that ought not to pas for a general rule.

We have often preed ome Vipers, both Males and Females, at the place, where be the Paratates, or the Bladders containing the eed, namely under the tail, and near the openings, which erve for generation; and have o much and o long pres'd them, that a white liquor came forth; but we never perceived there any piercing or ill-ented mell, no more than we did in opening thoe Paratates with a lance though we held our noe cloe to it: which is alo directly contrary to what ome Authors have aured thereof.

div.head: CHAPT. VIII.
GENERAL REFLEXIONS Vpon all we have experimented.
div.p: THE great care and attention ued by us in the Experiments, we have hitherto decribed, and in thoe, we have thought fit to uppres, hath made us to profit of all the occaions, that preented themelves; and we have taken pleaure to oberve all the effects, that have appeared to us, and carefully examined them, and inquired into their caues afterwards, that we might make our reflexions thereon.

The Biting of the Viper, which hapned to the Gentleman Stranger, began to furnih us with much matter; and at that time we knew the Venom by its effects, which eem'd to proceed from a very light caue, it being nothing but a little pricking, and onely the cut of a tooth, which was not any thing deep, and the ill of
which did not eem to us increaed by any of the yellow liquor of the Gums, the innocence of which was not yet fully known to us. In the mean time the mortal Accidents came on in great number, whilt continued vomitings hinder'd the effect of the remedies, which could not be kept in the Stomach, to communicate from thence ome of their vertue to the parts affected. It was well enough known, that there was omething very ubtile, very quick, and very powerful in this Venom; and it was alo preumed, that that reided in the Spirits; but the nature of it, or by what means, or how, or on what parts it acted, was not known o well.

Yet we mut avow, that on an occaion o preing, o dangerous, and o extraordinary, we could not take our meaures better than by having recoure to the Volatile Salt of Vipers. The caue being ubtile and pirituous, there was required a remedy of the like nature, that might be able to make hate to finde it out, to joyn with it, and to draw it to the extremities of the body, and to make it come forth by the wayes, it had opened for it. But then, the continual vomiting demanded
the aid of uch a remedy, that could work in a moment, or execute at leat by everal takings, what it was not able to do at the firt. The happy ucces, which attended the ue of this Volatile alt of Vipers, acquainted us with the ufficiency thereof, and howed us the matery it had over the malignity of thoe Spirits. It alo begot in us a deire to know aright, in what manner it produced uch good effects, and to be enabled o to dicoure of it, as that others might have no reaon to reject our entiments.

We eteem therefore, that this Salt, by its ubtile, volatile and piercing quality, is very proper to diolve the coagulations of the Bloud, and to ever the parts, which therein were congeal'd or fix'd, (if we may o peak) and caus'd the diorder and confuion of its motion; that it performed this in the Blood of the aid Gentleman, which it retor'd to its former condition, and o gave again to the parts the free communication of the Spirits, which they had lot. We believe alo, that this Volatile Salt, by the facility it had to hook and faten it elf unto thoe vexed Spirits, as being of the like nature,
did eaily joyn with them, and drove them to the extremities of the body, drawing them forth through the pores of the skin, and iuing out with them by the way, it had open'd for them.

The Ligatures made about the place bitten, the Scarifications, and the approach of the well heated iron-patuls to the wound, were to erve to tay the impetuounes of thoe irritated Spirits, and to give them an out-let at thee openings, rather than that they hould go farther: And the exhibition of the Theriaque, the Viper-powder, and the like, was to conduce to drive them back, as it might have done, if thee remedies had tay'd in the Stomach. As alo the Epithemes of Theriaque upon the Heart and Stomach might have erv'd much, if the action of the enrag'd pirits had been more low, and if at the time of their application thoe pirits had not been too farre advanced.

But the Ue of this Volatile Salt was to carry the Bell, as it did, from all the other remedies; and thoe, that were employ'd afterwards and in the intervals of its exhibition, were nothing, if we may
o peak, but Souldiers aiting their Captain; uch as the Confection of Alkermes and of Hyacinthe, which were very proper to fortify the noble parts; as alo were the Syrup of Limons, and the Decoction of Scorzonera, and the havings of Ivory.

The Slices of Citron, which might eem to ome by their acidity capable to augment the coagulation of the blood, were not given till after the Volatile Salt had ued its force to diipate it; and they erved to recover the Stomach, debilitated by continual vomiting, and by their acidnes to retore the lot appetite, and to help the concoction of the aliments, and their ditribution into the parts, that had need of them. Beides that Citrons have a pecifique vertue againt the poyon of Vipers, if we will believe thoe Authors, that have written of it; and is a great friend to the Heart and the other noble parts.

The Anointing with the Oyle of Scorpions of Matthiolus, and with the water of the Queen of Hungary, made upon the well'd parts, and the application of Alexiterial fomentations, hould in all appearance have erv'd much; but the equele
hew'd, that there was nothing but that Volatile Salt, which could make thoe angry Spirits urrender, and o was to take the honour of all.

The Experiments, which we afterwards made upon a great number of differing Animals, have given us a much greater knowledg of the effects of Vipers-poyon, of the parts on which it works, and of thoe that eem to be exempt from it, though at lat they do uccumbe: We have et down the mot coniderable of them, making ome reflexions on the biting of everal Doggs, done by Vipers; but there remain'd till for us to dicoure, Why and How the parts of Vipers, being eaten, can top and overcome the Venom of their biting.

We ay therefore, that all the parts of a Viper abound chiefly in Volatile Salt, which in ditillation is found partly alone; partly in the form of a Spirit, which properly is nothing but a Salt diolved in ome portion of Phlegme; and partly in the form of an Oyle, which alo is but a Salt mix't among the unctuous part of a Viper. We ay alo, that in the digetion, made in the Stomach, of the parts of a Vipers
body, that have been wallowed down, this ame Volatile Salt, which they contain, is eparated, and afterwards ditributed to all the parts that need them; epecially if of thee parts there have been wallow'd enow, to furnih that quantity, which is neceary, of this Salt; and o we need not doubt, but that this Salt will produce an effect like that of the Volatile Salt, which was given to our Gentleman bitten; Unles it hould be aid, that this ame Volatile Salt of thoe parts of a Vipers body, which have been wallowed, being of the ame nature with the irritated Spirits, attracts them to it elf, and by this union changes their maligne quality, and o tames them, that they have no power over the bitten Animal; which, in my opinion, is hard enough to conceive, and perhaps etablihed upon unolid foundations.

We hope, that among the many Experiments, thoe of the Five Pigeons, bitten one after another, by one and the ame Viper exaperated, and of which the lat bitten dyed firt of all, when the Viper was mot vexed, and mot exhauted of its yellow liquor; and that of the Pigeon bitten by
Viper, which we had caued to bite everal times into bread before, and that even till bloud came forth, to the end that the Juyce might be well emptied of it, and which notwithtanding was followed by the death of the Pigeon; Thee Experiments, I ay, will prove on one hand, that the yellow liquor contributes nothing to the poyon; and on the other, that thee incened Spirits, aited by the openings which the great Teeth had prepared for them, are the ole and true caue thereof.

The wound, made by a Viper not vexed, whoe jaws were held in, and whoe teeth were at the ame time thrut into the body of a Pigeon, which alo was accompanied with tore of the yellow juyce, and yet not attended with any ill accident; as alo the pricking, made by the great teeth, pulled out of a live Viper, or by uch, as tuck yet in the head of a dead Viper, and did no hurt at all, do ufficiently confirm this truth, viz. that the caue of the Venom is to be imputed to the Spirits enraged, and not to any other thing or parts in the Vipers body.

I have not undertaken to reaon upon
all the Experiments, we have made, as I have done upon the Bitings, both becaue that is beyond the Sphere of a man of my profeion, and becaue I deigned onely to confine my elf particularly to the wounds and to the Remedies able to heal them.

For the ret, if in the Treaty concerning Theriaque, which I have lately publiht, I have advanced any thing not cononant to what I have declared here, touching the action of the Venom, I am to be excued therein, foramuch as I had not then had the occaion, well to know the nature and the effects of the Bitings of Vipers, and referred my elf to the mot approved Authors about it. But yet all we have there aid, derogates in nothing from the preparation of Vipers for Theriaque, which we have there laid down, and which was in that Book our main deign, as well as to reform everal other preparations, that eemed not reaonable to us: That which now remains to be done by us, is, to peak of the Remedies to be drawn from Vipers, which may erve to heal their bitings, and to cure many other evils.

div.head: CHAPT. I.
Of the different choyce that may be made of the parts of a Viper.
div.p:
THere is nothing in Nature, to which can be given more jutly the title both of Aliment and Medicine, than to a Viper, ince it affords equally very good Nourihment and very good Remedies. It alo hath in its Body not one part, which is not very uefull, and of which Artits may not draw omething
that is good; their chief difference coniting in this, that the ubtance of the one is more or les cloe, then that of others. Yet, as in all Bodies of Animals, there are parts preferable to others, o we may make a ditinction of thoe in a Viper, epecially if we mean to eat them, or to reduce them to powder, to take it at the mouth, alone, or mingled with other medicaments.

In this cae, it will be well, to ue only the Heart, the Liver, and the Trunk, I mean, the Body emptied of its guts, without head and tayle. Not that, if you would make ue of the head and taile, any ill would attend it, or that you need to fear any ill quality in them, no more than in all the other parts of the body; but the Heart, Liver and Trunk are choen, as thoe that are mot eteem'd, and which are taken before the ret, out of the body of uch Animals, which men ue to feed upon. Thoe alo, that would nourih themelves with Viper-fleh boyled and eaoned, may do well, in eating of it, to eparate the bones thereof, and to leave them uneaten: but if they bruie them between their teeth,
and wallow them down together with the fleh, they would afford them a like, and even a tronger nourihment than the fleh: for, we have found by Ditillation, that the Bones yield the ame parts, that the Fleh does and even in greater quantity. For the ame reaon, the Bones of the trunk are not to be cat away, when you will prepare the powder of Vipers, and that the rather, becaue they are in that way very eay to wallow. One may alo very uefully dres the fleh of Vipers with their own fat, as one would do with butter, or with the fat of other animals. The Skin it elf, if men would, might be boyled and eaten with benefit; but that it would not be o avory, as the principal parts we have been peaking of.

As for the Chymical preparations, all the parts of Vipers may be therein employed, and I would not except from them the Stomach it elf, nor the Intetins, if they were well clear'd of Worms, and all Excrements.

I alo know no difference, as to goodnes, of one Sex from the other, although mot Authors have precribed the ue of Females: On the contrary, if there be
any uch difference, I would preferre the Males to the Females, when thee are full of Eggs, and big, foramuch as then they are too much wated for the feeding and increaing of their Eggs.

As to the Seaons, in which they are to be taken and ued, I almot equally conider the Spring and Autumne; for the times wherein men need them, ought to carry it in the behalf of thoe who have a mind to feed on them. But care mut be had to chue uch Vipers, as are bigg, fat, vigorous, and active; and not to keep them very long after they have been taken, becaue they grow leaner and leer every day, both out of Melancholy, and want of food, which after that time they ue not to take. I alo make no difference between thoe Vipers of France, that are bred in one Province, and thoe of another; for thoe of Poitou and the neighbouring parts are as good as thoe of Dauphine and about Lyons, and in other places. The place therefore is not to be conidered but for the quantity, and for the conveniency of getting them, in regard that they are not wont to be found in maritime places, which are the onely, that
Authors have diapproved for Vipers, upon the belief, that the fleh of Vipers, taken in them, did caue thirt, by reaon of the altih food, they met with there.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the e of the parts of Vipers, in repect of their nourihing Vertue.
div.p:
THere is carce an Author, that hath written of Vipers, but affirms, that in everal parts of the World, many perons, and even whole Nations, have fed, and till feed upon the fleh of Vipers; in omuch that in great and cotly Entertainments, they made exquiite and very coniderable dihes of it. There are alo, that have alledged for an example ome Nations, which by the ue of Viper-fleh,
have extraordinarily lengthn'd their life, even to 140. years. It is needles, to inert here the tetimonies of Antiquitie on this ubject; the Curious may finde them in Books. We content ourelves to affirm, that many perons do till ue it at this time in divers Countries, whether it be from Cutom, or to atisfie their appetite, or by the Advice of knowing Phyitians, and that upon occaions they finde wonderful effects thereof. I alo doubt not, but that the ue of it would be more frequent among us, if the vertues of Vipers were well known, and if one could dilodge out of the minde of people the horrour and natural antipathy, they have againt this animal. For the tate of Viper-fleh is very like that of Eeles; whence it is, that in ome Countries Vipers are called Eeles of the Mountain; and one finds omething in them even more avoury than in Eeles. I know perons, who well knowing the mot inward parts of Vipers, have out of merriment, and in company, made good meals of them, and found it very avory meat. But thoe that have too much averion from this kind of food, may find very convenient
wayes to benefit themelves by the vertue of them, o as not to be diverted from it by any abhorrency of the animal: for they may feed Capons and Pullets with the fleh of Vipers cut in mall pieces, which thoe Creatures eat very greedily; and continuing for ome time to feed them therewith, it will certainly communicate the vertue of the Vipers to the body of thoe Animals; which may be eaten, as we eate other Capons or Pullets, the tate of which will be very avoury, becaue that of Viper fleh is o.

Neither ought we to doubt, that the qualities of Vipers pas into the bodies of thoe animals, ince there are innumerable others, the fleh of which hath not onely the vertue, but even the tate of the things, they are fed with. The fleh of the Birds, that live on Juniper-berries, and of thoe, that live onely upon Olives, hath not onely their qualities, but alo their tate and bitternes, and that o highly, that one can care eat them. In the Countries, where Silk-worms are bred, it is oberved, that in their eaon, which is chiefly in the months of May and June, the Eggs of Hens, that eat thoe Worms,
have a tate and mell of them, as well as their fleh; inomuch that nice perons feed their Poultry a part, and hinder them from eating any Silk-worms. It may be taken notice of, to this purpoe, that 'tis a cutome to give to Nures the medicines, which young Children cannot be made to take, to the end that their vertue may pas from the body of the Nure to that of the Child; and it hath been often oberv'd, that the Urine of the Babe hath had the ent of the Druggs the Nure had taken.

But yet ome might phany, that Animals cannot take the good from the good parts of the things eaten by them, but they mut at the ame time receive the impreions of the ill ones, that are there; and it might even be objected, that Lizzards, Scorpions, Cantharides, and the other Creatures, on which Vipers do feed, hould impres in their bodies the ill qualities, they have, as, among the ret, the Cantharid, its Cautique quality. But notwithtanding all this, the Experience we have of the harmlesnes of Vipers-bodies, and alo of their good qualities, furnihes us with a contrary argument, ufficient
to detroy that phany; and it teaches us, that the tomach of Animals converteth into good all the ill qualities, to be met with in the bodies, it receiveth to diget; and that it uniteth and appropriateth the good ones to the very ubtance of the Animal that hath eaten them: Whence it comes to pas, that it is as 'twere transformed, or at leat very much changed by thoe good qualities; and is upon that account capable to communicate them to other animals, into whoe tomach it enters to be there digeted. We ay beides, that there are divers Examples of Bodies, that would be altogether poyonous in the tomach of men, which yet erve for food to, and fatten, other animals, which afterwards yield good nourihment to men. Such are Hellebore and Hemlock, which nourih and fatten Quailes and Goates, which afterwards are uefully employed for the nourihment of men; and this is it, what Lucrece hath very well oberved in thee Veres;
Praeterea nobis Veratrum et acre venenum,
At Capris adipes & Coturnicibus auget:
Quippe videre licet pinguecere saepe Cicutâ
Barbigeras pecudes; homini quae et acre Venenum.

But thoe, that have no averion from Vipers-fleh, may take of them the Heart, the Liver, and the Trunck, and having wahed them well, they may then accommodate them to their own tate in the dreing. Where they are to take care, not to make the fleh too hot by too much pice epecially pepper; but yet they are allowed to put to it ome aromatique herbs, as Garden- and Wild-Thyme, and the like; or a little Nutmeg, Cinamon, Cloves, to raie the tate. They mut alo avoid the fault, committed by the Antients, whipping and vexing the Vipers, before they killed them; leat this irritation hould caue ome ill impreion in their body, which by it elf hath no venom at all in it. Let them alo not cat away the broth, wherein the Vipers have been boyled, becaue it retaines the greatet vertue of them. Neither do I ee, why one hould tint the quantity, or limit the time of the ue of it; that depending from the degree
of the illnes, and from the contitution of the perons, that will make ue thereof. And although we know Vipers to be a very Alterative Medicine, and that their chief ue is onely for their Medicinal qualities; yet if taken as an Aliment, there is no danger at all to eat of their fleh, or to drink of their broth, omewhat more or omewhat les. It is alo to be moderately alted; and thoe that have any of the Fixed Salt of Vipers, hall do well to employ it. You may alo adde to it ome of its Volatile Salt, if you will have the Fleh of Vipers work more powerfully.

As to the Vertues of Viper-fleh, according to the conent of innumerable Authors, whoe opinion is upported by reaon and truth, confirmed by many Experiments; we can ay, that they are very great, and that there is no Animal in Nature, that affords uch and o many: And we wonder not at all, that the Antients have o frequently employ'd Vipers in their Hieroglyphicks, and adorned their Medals with them; thereby to deign very advantagious things for the publick, and for private men; forasmuch as this Animal is very capable to furnih them. For
the ue of it preerves the natural heat in a very good temper, it repaireth the ame, and retoreth it when 'tis altered; it yields a very good food; helps digetion by its heat, which is not exceive; it retards old age and prolongeth life, by a property, which Vipers have, to maintain in good plight the whole habit of the Body. Whence it is, that many have believed, that both Staggs and Eagles, induced to it by a natural intinct, eat all the Vipers, they can meet with, and that 'tis upon that core, that their life is extraordinary long.

There is alo adcribed to Vipers, and not without reaon, a Renewing vertue, capable to make young again; which they tacitly hew, by cating their skin twice a year, and renewing themelves by the cover of a new skin. This, joyned to the ubtile parts, of which the Viper is compoed, and to its lively and daring apect, tetifies it to be pertinent enough, that Authors have attributed to it the vertue of clearing and trengthning the Eyes.

Vipers have alo a very particular vertue of Cleaning the whole Body, and particularly the Bloud, and of expelling
through the pores of its skin all the uperfluities: Whence it may be inferred, that they are very proper to cure the Itch, Tettar, Eryipelas or Saint Anthonies fire, Meaels, Small Pox, and the Leproy it elf, the ue of them being long enough continued; though I cannot well believe what Galen aith, That the Wine, wherein one onely Viper is choaked, is able to cure o great an Evil, and which doth not o eaily yield to remedies.
Vipers alo may, by removing all the impurities and obtructions of the Body and skin, caue beauty therein; and upon this account it is, that many Ladies in Italy ue them for their ordinary food.

By the good nourihment, they yield by the purity they give to the blood and to all the parts, and by the liberty they give to the Spirits to do their functions therein, they are a great relief to perons in a Conumption, and to thoe that are emaciated by long dieaes, and wated by tedious Feavers. There are even Authors, who aure that the ue of them is capable to cure the Venereal dieae; for which we doubt not but they may erve much, if they do not altogether cure it.

Their mundifying vertue, joyned to the Alexiterial, makes them alo very proper to expell all orts of poyons, and even the Plague it elf and all contagious dieaes. They are alo very contrary to all putrefaction, which commonly is the matter and ource of mot maladies; whence it comes, that thoe who ue them, are not ubject to dieaes, unles they live irregularly, which is able to detroy all the good, which the ue of Vipers might afford.

We might here pecify many other icknees, that might be cured by the ue of Viper-fleh; but we think not fit to do o, ince the general vertues, which we have noted, may uffice to make men apply the ue to many particular Evils, that may need it. Yet we hall decribe, in the Chapter enuing, the ues and Vertues of the parts of Vipers, taken as a Medicine, without any great preparation.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Vertues of everal parts of the iper, and of their Ve in Phyick.
div.p: THE Vertues, which the Fleh of Vipers is able to communicate to thoe, who eat them for nourihment, are doubtles very coniderable; but they are not the onely ones, that Vipers are endow'd with; and not to alledge uperfluous things, we hall confine our elves to the principal Vertues, of which we have experimented the greatet part.

It is very certain, that the Head of a Viper, broyled and wallowed, healeth the biting of that animal. The Heart and the Liver may do the ame. Reaon and Experience have confirm'd it; and therefore
in an urgent occaion thoe parts may be very uefully employed. The application of the Blood of a Viper to the Biting, as alo that of its Head bruied, are neither to be rejected, nor is that of the Entralls: but thee applications alone are not capable to cure it; for, the ubtlety and quicnes of the Spirits carrying them with great peed into the body, there mut be ued internal pecifick remedies to repule them; and you may alo very pertinently repeat (at the mouth) the ue of the head, heart, liver, and the other parts of a Viper, without fearing to take too much of them, becaue thoe parts can never do hurt, and they alwayes produce ome good effect. They may alo erve for all orts of venoms and poyons, and againt all orts of contagious and epidemical dieaes.

Divers Authors aure, that the Head of a Viper, hung about the neck, hath a very particular quality to cure the Squinancy and all the ditempers of the Throat; and that the Brain of a Viper, wrapt up in a little skin, and likewie hung about the neck, is very good to make the Teeth of children come forth; which effect
others believe to be due to the great teeth of Vipers. If we had experimented it, we could then peak with more certainty. The remedies are eaily practicable, and withal harmles; wherefore thoe who need them may make tryal of them.

Some alo have affirmed, that the Liver of a Viper, wallowed, keeps one from being bitten either by this Animal, or by any other erpent, and that the powder of Vipers hath the ame efficacy. But we mut not rely upon their report; we onely believe, that the Liver wallowed is capable to heal the biting of a Viper; like the heart, fleh, and other parts, of which we have poken; and that it may much facilitate the delivery of Women with child, as doth the Liver of Eeles.

The Skin of a Viper is not altogether detitute of vertue; for beides that it is alo, as they ay, very good for the delivery of women, making a garter of it about the right leg, it hath a very ingular vertue for all the ditempers of humane skin: And although all the other parts, eaten, may work the ame thing; yet, that we might have benefit from all, we have experimented, that the Viper-skin does perfectly
heal the inveterate mangie of Dogs, making them eat it boyled or raw. It might alo be aid, that the pecks in the Viper-skin eem to ignify the marks of the itch or mangy, or, if you will, of the leproy, which the cales of the skin repreent yet better, and o tacitly expres its vertue.

Some have believed, that the Gall of a Viper applyed, can heal its biting; but we give no credit to it, no more than to the application of its bruied head. But this we judge, that it is proper for the wound of the biting, onely as it is for all other wounds, and for ulcers themelves, having a great abterive, mundifying and cicatrizing vertue. It is alo very good for the weaknees of Eyes, above all, for uffuions and films, being taken inwardly, or applied outwardly; o far it is from doing them hurt.

The Fat of Vipers hath very great vertues; for, beides that it is very good in the dreing of the Viper-fleh (as hath been aid) it is able alo, taking a drachm of it, to give great relief in Epidemical dieaes, and to expell the venom thereof. It is alo very ueful to facilitate the travel of women; and to diipate the wellings of
the throat, anointing it outwardly therewith. It alo much relieves Gouty perons, and erves to reolve nodoities. It unwels all hard and inveterate tumors, and even thoe that proceed from Venereal dieaes; and for this reaon 'tis, that Jean de Vigo hath ued it in the Plaiter which bears his name. It is likewie very good for Burnings, putuls,' and all ditempers of the skin; and latly, it is very powerful againt all the illnees of the Sinews, and of great vertue for the parts attackt by the Paly. We might alo adde many other vertues, adcribed by Authors to other parts of the Viper; but we forbear, becaue we have not experimented them.

div.head: CHAPT. IV.
Of the Powder and Trochiques of Vipers.
div.p:
SInce we do not alwayes meet with perons, who, having need to make ue of Viper-fleh, are dipoed to eat thereof; it is very neceary to have ready uch remedies, that be as well accommodated to the inclination of the Patient, as fitted to remove the malady. The knowledge, which Phyitians have bad of the great Vertues of the Viper, joyned to the difficulty, met with in the point of pleaing Patients, hath obliged them to earch for divers Preparations, in which the Antients did not well ucceed; and if we would bind ourelves to their way of preparing the Powder and the Trochiques, we hould looe the principal vertue of the Viper, and retain onely the mot ueles. For, in the opinion, which they entertained,
that there remain'd alwayes ome venom in the fleh of the Viper, if it were not freed therefrom by ome preparation or other; their practice was, to put the fleh of Vipers in ome earthen pot, and having luted it, to et it in a Bakeoven, after the Bread was drawn out, and to leave it there, till this fleh was reduced to powder. In which preparation the bet of this fleh, which is the Volatile Salt, was certainly diipated. They alo made everal medicines with this powder, mixt among other medicaments divers wayes; of which we need not to enlarge. We hall content ourelves, here to et down a preparation of the Powder of Vipers, which hall be grounded on Reaon, and hall retain all the vertues of the Viper; eay alo to prepare, and very convenient for the Patient to ue.

Take then towards the end of Aprill, or in the beginning of May, uch a quantity of Vipers as you pleae, Males and Females, chuing big ones, and uch as are fat and vigorous, and uing none of thoe Females, which are already big with eggs; and then prepare thoe, you hall have thus choen, as follows: Without whipping and vexing
them, cut off, with a pair of izers, their heads and tailes, flea them, and empty them of all their entrals, of which you are to eparate the heart and the Liver; and lay aide their fat for its peculiar ues. Wah the trunks of the bodies, the hearts and livers in clear water, and after that in white wine; then dry them with a very clean linnen cloth, and having put the hearts and livers again into their trunks, tye all the trunks with mall pack-thred, each at one end, and hang them up in the air in the hade, and leave them there, till they be well dryed; which will be in three or four dayes. After that, cut thee trunks into mall pieces, and tamp them in a great Bras-mortar with an iron-petle, and earce all through a very fine hairive, and o keep it for ue. This is the right Powder of Vipers, which contains all the vertues; to which may be added a drop of Cinamon-oyle, to give it a good cent.

There are ome, who, to make this powder would have the trunks of Vipers cut in pieces, and put together with their hearts and livers in a Glas-cucurbit, and this covered with its head and luted, and
o placed with a recipient, in a very gentle Balneum; thereby, continuing that warmth for three dayes together, to draw the phlegm of Vipers, accompanied with a mall portion of the Volatile Salt, and to keep this liquor apart; and then to take out of the Cucurbite what hall remain there, and of it to make the powder of Vipers.

But, beides that this method is troubleome enough; that the fire of a Balneum is not ufficiently trong to end forth enough of the Volatile Salt, at a time when 'tis not yet looen'd from its ubject; that 'tis notwithtanding too much o, not to emit inenibly ome mal portion, which would afterwards be wanting in the Powder, and which alo may exhale out of the water; beides alo that the Vipers are in danger to be too much dry'd in the Cucurbite, and even to be there roted in part: We eteem, there is caue to prefer our Preparation to this, in regard it is much eaier, and, without any detruction or alteration of the good parts of Vipers, carries away all their uperfluous and ueles humidity.

You might notwithtanding follow this
way in part, if you hould deire to have good Viper-water; but then you mut increae the fire of the Balneum, and finih the ditillation in much les time, and yet take heed not to haten the fire too much at the latter end, leat the water mell of the Empyreuma or burning. You mut alo, after you have taken out the parts of the Viper, that ret in the Cucurbite, put them into a glas-retort well luted, and et this into a reverberating furnace, dapt and exactly lute to it a great Recipient, and give it a fire increaed by degrees, and hotter about the end, to obtain the Volatile Spirit, Salt, and Oyle, that could not rie by the fire of the Balneum; which are to be eparated and rectifyed, as we hall ay hereafter. Then take a portion of this Volatile Salt well rectified, and diolve it in ditilled water, and keep it carefully in a well topp'd bottle, as an excellent remedy; of which you may increae or diminih the doe, according to perons and occaions; and according as you hall have diolved more or les of the Volatile Salt in it.

Upon this occaion, I thought fit to advertie thoe, who ditill Capons, Partridges,
lices of Veal, or other parts of Animals, in a Glas-limbec (as the cutom is,) and who employ for that purpoe the fire of a Balneum, or that of Sand or Ahes; that by a moderate fire they cannot make rie almot any thing but ueles flegm; and that, not being able to increae the fire without making the ditilled water mell of the Empyreuma, they would ucceed better, if in this they did, what I was jut now aying of the water and volatile Salt of Vipers; and if they joyn'd their water with the volatile Salt of the ditilled Animals, in which reides the chief vertue. Thoe, that have no mind to take o much pains, hall do better not to give ditilled waters to their Patients, as the cutom is, ince they have no vertue at all, if none be communicated to them by the volatil Salt of the Animal,

As to the Trochiques, the Antients have as ill invented, and as ill ordered them as the Powder. For, not to tay to blame here (as I have done elewhere) the whipping, which they ued, and which was not onely ueles, but alo very noxious; I hall ay in a few words, that the decoction, they made of the body of the
Viper in Water, with Salt and Anie, till the fleh would ever from the bones, which they afterwards cat away as well as the broth, was not a Preparation of the fleh of the Viper, but rather a detruction, ince it was made to leave its principal vertue in the broth; and that they weaken'd it yet more, by incorporating it with very dry bread, of which the proportion of a fifth to four times as much weight of fleh, though but little in appearance, came yet to a moiety, ince that four ounces of this fleh, and one ounce of bread (which was o dry that it could not be leened) make onely two ounces of Trochiques, when they are well dry'd. This we have more at large examined in our Treatie of the Theriaque; and becaue their fault is very eaily undertood, I hall init on it no farther; nor on their reaons for making ue of Boyling to correct a malignity in the fleh, (of which there is none) and to be able to ever it from the bones, which they believe naught, or at leat unuefull, which yet are very good; foramuch as all their reaons are ufficiently refuted in the ame Book, and becaue they are yet more o, by what we have etablih'd in this.
