And although it be not alwayes neceary to make Trochiques of Vipers, ince we might be without them; yet there being ome ue of them, and to preerve their name, you may take a little Gumm Arabique, very white and pure, and reduce it to powder, and infue it in good Malvay, till it be well diolv'd, and the wine omewhat tinged thereof: then take of the powder of Viper, prepar'd as we have lately directed, and incorporate it with a ufficient quantity of this gumm'd Malvay, braying them together in a Marblemortar with a woodden-petle, and o reduce the whole into a omewhat olid pate; whereof make Trochiques, of the ize and hape you pleae, and dry them in the hade upon a hair-ive.

I aid, that we might be without Trochiques, becaue that having the Powder, which they are made of, that may uffice for our ues; but there is one inconveniency in the Powder, in that it will carce keep any coniderable time, epeally if it be not well topt up, and if, beides; ome art be not ued to hinder the breeding of worms in it: Whereas Trochiques, being made compleat by the addition
of Malvay, and by the cloe compreion of the parts of the Powder, they are not o eaily penetrated by the Air, nor o ubject to corruption. The Trochiques being dry, they may be lightly rubbed over with a little Balom of Peru, which will give them a good cent, and help to preerve them.

The Ue both of the Powder and Trochiques is excellent and alike; but the Trochiques are to be reduced into powder, when they are to be ued. Neither of them have an ill tate, and they contain all the vertues, we have acribed to the Fleh of Vipers, as having lot nothing in drying, made without the heat of the Sunbeams, but a uperfluous moiture, which could erve for nothing but corrupt them, if it had remained. They may be given in cordial waters, broths, wine, or ome fit decoction, or you may make Bolus's of them with Syrrups, Conerves, or Cordial Confections, or turn them into tablets with ugar.

Their main effect is, to purify, open, penetrate, and to drive to the extremities of bodies all venom, corruptions, impurities, uperfluities, and they may be very beneficially
ued in many occaions for divers maladies, without the fear of any ill ucces. For both have this quality, that they do alwayes ome good, but never any harm. Their doe is from a Scruple to a drachm or two; and they may be given to all ages, and exes, and at all times.

div.head: CHAPT. V.
Of the Salt of Vipers made by the Ancients.
div.p:
AMong many different Preparations of the Salt of Vipers, made by the Ancients, of which we finde the decriptions in their Books, there is none more famous, nor that hath been longer in ue, than one that is very ample and much enriched by many Alexiterial remedies; whence tis alo, that they gave to this Salt the name of Theriacal. But having conidered this pompous Preparation,
we do not wonder, that a much eteemed Author hath not given it his approbation, ince we cannot finde any thing in it, that is according to rule or reaon, no more than there is in the ret. We finde, that the entiments of that Author proceed from an undertanding o judicious, and o knowing, that we cannot but ubcribe to them, almot in all: For, in the Calcination, they ued, there remain'd nothing but the fix't Salt, which contains but very little vertue; Vipers, as all orts of Animals, having but little of Fixt Salt, whereas they have much of the Volatile, which oon rieth in the Calcination, and carries away with it the principal and the mot eential vertue of the Animal. They were alo much mitaken, when they thought, that four Vipers, which they burn'd with fourty pounds of Sea-alt, or Sal Gemmae, or Sal Ammoniac, (as ome would have it) and with a great quantity of Simples, hould communicate great vertues to thee Salts and thee Coales. For in the Calcination, which they ued to make in an earthen pot luted, with its cover on, and yet in one place pierced, the Volatil Salt of the
four Vipers would certainly fly quickly away; and if it had tay'd (which yet we do not grant) and there had been half an ounce of it (which is a quantity beyond what the four greatet Vipers could yield,) what, I pray, would that be to 40. pounds of Sea-alt, and to many pounds of Coales, more than a mall rivolet mingled with the Ocean? But as to the fixt Salt, four Vipers are not able to afford half a Scruple of it.

'Tis alo certain, that both the Sea-alt and Sal gemme, do not perih in the Calcination, but till remain there. But if ordinary Salt Ammoniac be employed, the Urinous and Volatile part, which is in that Salt, will not fail to make its ecape, as well as the Volatile Salt of Vipers, and there will onely remain the fixt Saline part of the Salt Ammoniac, mix't with ome terretrial parts; which is that, we finde in the Ditillation, after we have driven out all the Volatile Salt, of which afterwards, changing the veel and the fire, we draw an acid pirit, very much approaching to that, we draw out of Sea-Salt, by wayes almot like thee.

Artits know alo, that Herbs, Wood,
Horns, Bones, and other uch like matters, if they hould be calcined in an earthen pot, luted and covered, though a hole were left in the cover, would alwayes be afterwards found in the form of very black coales, although they had endured a great fire; and that the Salt cannot be eparated from them, unles they be calcin'd again in an open veel; or they being reduced to ahes, the Salt be then ever'd from them by a Lixivium, and by Filtration.

On which occaion we relate an Example of an imperfect Calcination, which is naturally made in the Earth about the Summer-Soltice, of the end of the root of many Plants, and among others, of Mugwort and Plantatin; on which end, the ubterraneous Fire, or, if you will, the Fire of the Sun, working, and yet being urrounded by the Earth, (which is to the root what the earthen pot, luted, is to the Vipers, and to the Mixts, that were hut up with them) burns it and reduces it to coales, but cannot turn it to ahes. I have often found this to be true, and lighted upon a little coal at the end of the root of thoe Plants, at the time above-mentioned.

So that, although the Fixt Salt of the added
be Simples in the Coales, yet it would have been more proper, and more methodical, to have quite calcined thoe coales to reduce them to ahes, and o to draw from them and to purify the Salt for ue, than to make people wallow the gros, earthy, and ueles part of thee coales.

Thoe Antients added to this pretended Salt calcin'd, the powder of many Alexiterial Druggs, which not being deveted of their vertue by any calcination, may communicate, and even alone furnih the greatet part of the good qualities, by them acribed to this Salt. And 'tis upon the account of thee principally, that the name of Theriacal may belong to it, which impertinently would be attributed to the Vipers, ince they have lot their prime vertue in the Calcination.

This Preparation of Theriacal Salt doth ufficiently hew us, that the Antients did not take pains to know the inward parts, of which mix't bodies are compounded, and that they did not well know the nature of the poyon of Vipers, of which they imagin'd they hould be infected by the fumes proceeding from their Calcination; although none could come from
them, when there was none, as we have made appear. And although the mell, as well of the Vipers, as of the Simples, were troubleome, whilt they burned, yet they were not therefore at all venomous.

The little knowledge, which the Antients had, and many Moderns till have, of the nature of the two Salts in Vipers, hath led them into a great fault, viz. to calcine the bones of Vipers, to draw from thence, as they thought, the true Salt of Vipers, which they were not at all like to finde, after they had diipated it by Calcination. The firt fault hath drawn after it a econd; for the mall quantity of fix't Salt, they found in them, not much atisfying them, carried thoe, that had no great ene of honour or concience, to a very great abue, which was, to mix among thoe calcin'd bones a great quantity of Sea-alt, to diolve this Salt, and and to boyle all together in water, to filter and coagulate it, and to ell at a great rate this Counterfeit alt for true Salt of Vipers.

But, to accommodate ourelves to thoe, who, intending better, will make
no ill ue of it; and to furnih them with a pleaing Salt for thoe, that may deire it for ordinary ue; we hall here deliver the way of preparing a Salt of Viper, that hall have much vertue; the method of which hall be very eay, and the ue very convenient.

Take three dozen of great Vipers, well choen; cut off their heads and tails, flea them, and empty the bodies of all their entrals, and wah them well, together with the Heart and Liver: Boyl all together in ten pints of common water, o long till all be perfectly boyled. Then train it, and queee well all the parts; and in this decoction diolve four pounds of Sea-alt; and carefully filter it; afterwards, coagulate, or, if you will, chrytallize this Salt, which will be found white and abounding with the vertue of the Vipers, and of no ill tate at all; which you may ue in all things as common Salt.

And to hew, that thee boyled and queeed parts have left much of their vertue in the Decoction, and yet that they have not left all, and that till there remains ome of it, principally in the Bones; lay them abroad, and dry them, and then
ditill them, and you will draw from them, epecially from the Bones, a Volatile Salt and oyl, but in much les quantity, then if they had not been boyld.

If you would have a Viper-Salt of more vertue, and that might even be call'd Theriacal, you mut proceed after the ame manner, as hath been lately et down; but in tead of Seal-Salt, take a like quantity of Salt, drawn from Alexiterial and Theriacal Plants, as the roots of Valerian, Imperatoria, Angelica, Leaves of Scordium, the little Centaurium, Carduus Benedictus, and the like. 'Tis true, that this Salt is a little more dipleaing to the tate than the former, but it may produce more coniderable effects, and be ued in extraordinary occaions.

Thee orts of Salt have indeed good vertue, and are convenient for lating, epecially the two firt: But the Volatile Salt hath omething more particular, and coniderably better: the properties of it are innumerable, and it is an Epitome of the excellent qualities, contained in Vipers. We hall now peak of its Preparation, as alo of the Phlegm, of what is called volatile Spirit and Oyle, which accompany
it; and of the Fixt Salt, which remains after ditillation, mixed among the terretrial parts; and that done, we hall treat of their vertues and uefulnes.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Volatile Salt of Vipers, and the Fixt Salt, and other parts, which are eparated by Ditillation.
div.p:
WE make here publick our Preparation of the Volatile Salt of Vipers, with the more franknes and chearfulnes, becaue we eteem it one of the bet Medicines in Phyick. 'Tis true indeed, that ome Authors have already poken of it; but there is none, that hath decribed it with more exactnes, than
we, nor that hath more deired, that every one might, according to this Method, obtain for himelf and his occaions a remedy, which goes beyond many others, to ay no more. We hope, that our way of proceeding will be well received by all, and that, if there be any that hall finde fault with it, they will be uch only, who are unwilling to communicate what they have, and often wrap it up under the name of Secrets.

Take onely the Bodies, Hearts and Livers of Vipers, or, (to have the more benefit of all) add to them the Heads, Tails, and skins, and generally all the parts of a Viper; of which you will have a care to take away all the Excrements and Worms, as alo the Eggs, that may be in the Matrix of the Females. Small and great, Males and Females are of the ame goodnes, as alo the Salt is, that hall have been drawn from all the parts of the Body. Dry in the hade all thee parts eparately, then cut them into bits, and fill with them your Glas-limbec up to the neck, which is to be well luted. Put it in the midt of a Reverberating furnace, proportion'd to its bignes, cover it with its
head, and hut the Regiter of it; Fit to the Limbec a Glas-recipient, which mut be very large; and lute well all the joynts. Then begin to give a mall fire, which continue for about two hours, o that the Limbec be heated gradually, and the Phlegme begin to ditil into the Recipient. Afterwards increae the fire gently unto a econd degree; and give a little opening at the Regiter, and continue the ame fire likewie two hours; then increae it, opening the Regiter yet more, and o continue two other hours; at the end of which you are to give it the fire of the lat degree, quite opening the Regiter, and you mut continue to drive the fire, till no more come out of the Limbec, and the Recipient be all obcured by the Volatile Salt, which will tick to its ides, towards the bottom, and to the upper part. Then let the veells cool, and the Furnace alo; after which you are to un-lute the Recipient, wherein you will finde the Phlegme, that part which is called Spirit, the Volatile Salt, and the Oyle mingled together; except a part of the Volatile Salt, that may yet adhere to the upper part, and to the ides of the Recipient, which you may dexterouly
take away, and, if you will, keep for ue, as 'tis. This Volatile Salt, Spirit, and Oyle, are o penetrating, that you are not able to hold your noe over it.

Powre out, what you find in the Recipient, into a Glos-Body, which mut be large, tall, broad below, and whoe figure goes up traightning towards the orifice; to which you mut adapt a Glas-head, that is to have omewhat a high body, and large, and a very traight mouth, and proportioned to that of the Glas-body. Lute the joynts exactly with paper and tarch; put the Body in a Sand-bath, and ink it down as low as the matter reacheth; fit a mall Recipient to the beak of the Head, and lute that alo: kindle under it a very gentle fire, and order it o, that the Sand and the Glas-body may be heated gently; after which you may increae it a little, but onely o as to make it trong enough to drive up the Volatile Salt; which, being di-engag'd from the parts of the Vipers bodies, rieth eaily. It will be ublimed, and tick every where to the inide of the Head, like a Chrytallized Snow. There will arie at the ame time a little of the Spirit, which is properly nothing
but a portion of the Volatile Salt, having carried up with it a little of the Phlegme, that will run into the little Recipient, and of which even a part will congeal into Chrytals. You mut alwayes be careful in managing the Fire; for how little oever you increae it, the Phlegme will rie with ome of the Oyle, and they will diolve and hide the Salt; and then you mut recommence the Rectification; but governing the fire well, when you hall ee the Head well lined with Salt, which will be very white and very Chrytalline, you mut then un-lute it, and take it off, and lute on an other head, intead of the former. You are to take out the Salt, as oon and as well as you can; and to encloe it in a trong bottle, with uch a mouth, that the Salt may pas through it, and which may be exactly cloed, without which the Salt will eaily fly away. Mean time, you are to continue a like fire under the Glas-body, and when no more of that Volatile rieth, you are to deit, and to take out of the head the Salt there gathered, and keep it as the former. Your Sand being cold, take off the Glas-body, and decant from it the remainder through a great
Glas-funnel, covered with paper for filtration, held over ome veell. All the Phlegm will pas thorough the Paper; but you'l finde ome Oyle there, that cannot pas, which you may make run through the Funnel into a bottle, having pierced the paper with ome convenient intrument.

Thoe that hall deire a high and much more perfect Rectification of this Volatile Salt, may make it in manner following. Take two pounds of Ivory calcin'd to whitenes, and reduced to a fine powder; which is to be mixt with four ounces of this Salt. Then put all into a new Glas-Body, of the ame hape with the former. To this let there be adapted and luted a blind Head, or uch an one, the extremity of whoe beak is well topp'd (for that is ueles for this purpoe, there being no phlegme; and if there were, the calcin'd Ivory being a dry Body, and in part pungy, would lick and retain it, as it would alo the Oily part, that might happen to be among the Volatile Salt:) let there be given to this Glas-body a moderate Fire, with the ame cautions as before; the Salt will quickly rie, and tick to the Head;
where, the Sublimation being ended, you will finde it in the form of Chrytals, white like now; which you are to put up and keep in a bottle exactly cloed, to ue it upon occaion. This Salt thus rectified mells not of Fire, and hath nothing but its own natural trong and penetrating cent.

There may perhaps be found Artits, who will take it ill, that we have been o large and o particular in exactly etting down all the things, that are to be oberved in preparing and rectifying this Salt. But it is not for them, that we have done it, but for thoe, who not knowing it will be glad to learn it. We have given them incerely the true means ued by ourelves; which they may alo practie in preparing and rectifying the Salts of the parts of all Animals. Thoe that have any tincture of Chymitry, will here find enough to teach themelves; as we have done, and do daily. Mean time they mut not be offended, that there remain with us upon this ubject uch things, which could not be aid, nor well comprehended but by thoe that have labour'd a great while in this Art. Intelligent perons, that
hall examine our proceeding, or have a mind to experience the ame, will find our ingenuounes, by finding the ucces of all we have made them expect, together with the facility, we give, of the Operation. They will alo find, that our way of filling the Retort as far as the neck, is more proper than that of leaving a third part empty, as ome would have it, in the Ditillation of the Bones, Horns, and other dry parts of Animals; although thoe, that undertand it, practice it not but in matters that will melt, and may break the Retort, or let omething run out by the beak, when 'tis fill'd too high. But in dry ubtances, as are our Vipers, and the Horns, and Bones of Animals, Crabseyes, Stones, and the like, it is enough to leave this neck empty, to give vent to the parts raied from the matter, and that are to go into the Recipient. They will alo acknowledge, that our way to leave the Oyl among the other ubtances, when we will ever them by ubliming and rectifying them, is not without reaon, in regard that the Oyl hath commonly with it much Volatile Salt, which leaves it, and afterward rieth in the Rectification.

We eteem alo, that this Preparation will be preferr'd before many others, that are operoe and have little method in them; and, among others, before the Rectification, which ome pretend to make by the addition of Spirit of Salt to the Phlegme, and to that which is call'd Spirit, and to the Volatil Salt: which intead of rectifying this Salt, and of making it purer and better, changes its nature; and intead of ubliming it to the Head and the top of the Body (as they have pretended it did, after the Phlegm was rien,) the Spirit of Salt rieth it elf in its firt form, in its mell, colour and tate, leaving at the bottom the Salt, which is there found like fixed, having the tat and the other qualities of the Spirit of Salt, but being leen'd of two thirds of its weight. That kind of men have fill'd Books with many Preparations they undertand not, nor have experimented: For, forgetting, among other things, in the proces of this, uch methods as are abolutely neceary, and without which they do nothing, they promie impoible uccees, and putting the Cart before the Hores, they fix the Salt when they pretend to ublime it, and
o very unadviedly protitute themelves to hame and confuion. For, intead of rectifying firt the Volatile Salt (as more intelligent men might have taught them, of whom they had borrowed this Preparation) and of ubliming it, and of eparating it by this means from other parts; they labouring to diguie the Proces, have retrenched the main and mot neceary part of it, and employed at the very firt that method, which they hould have oberv'd to fix it, believing that that would ublime it; not conidering, that having by that means inverted nature, the ucces would prove anwerable to it. I et a ide their unwarrantable practice of adding a pound of luke-warm water among the ubtances found in the Recipient, after the firt ditillation, ince it is an Augmentation, not onely ueles, but troubleome, of that Phlegme, which mut needs be eparated.

Now, although one part of this Salt, remaining in the Body of the Limbec, may yet afterwards becom Volatil, by mixing it with ome Lixiviat Salt, and making it to ublime; yet that is not done but with a new and very great los of its weight;
nor is the tate of it better than of that, which hall have been well rectified according to the method, we have before decribed; ince the Lixiviat Salts, by reviving it in part, give it as dipleaing a mel as the former. We may further add here, that the ue of tall and trait-neck't Bodies is much more proper for this Rectification, than the ue of Matraes with long necks, myelf having experimented, that the Phlegme fals back again more eaily, and that the Volatil Salt rieth purer in the Bodies of our fahion; of which the Figure may be een on the Title page, where alo is that of the Retort and the Recipient, for the firt Ditillation.

Now although the ame men, that have given us caue to reprehend them, have affirmed contrary to truth, that there is no fix't Salt in the parts of Animals: To prove that there is, and to benefit by that of the Viper; Take what hall remain in the Retort, commonly called the Caput Mortuum, which you will find of the form and colour of Coales; calcine it in a Furnace, or, to ave expences, in a Potters Oven, till all become white and of the form of Chalk, pulverize it
well, and make it boyl in a competent quantity of water, that may receive and diolve the Salt; filter it, and make it euaporate and conume. You'l find at the bottom a coagulated Salt; though in a mall quantity, and uch an one, as that of five pounds of Viper-bones well calcin'd, we have obtain'd no more than three ounces of fix't Salt. This Salt hath a very harp and poynant tate; it is Lixiviat, and approaching enough in divers regards to the fixt Salt of Tartar. You'l find on the Filter the Terretrial part, tripp'd of all its vertue; which then may jutly be call'd Caput Mortuum. And thus you'l have the Phlegme, that which is call'd Spirit, the Volatil Salt, the Oyl, the Fixt Salt, and the Earth; into which all the parts of the Viper have been reduced in their eparation.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Fixation of the Volatil Salt of Vipers.
div.p:
ALthough the Volatile Salt of Vipers have in it, to peak truth, nothing offenive, but its trong and piercing Smell, and that thoe, who hall take into their mouth the weight of a good number of grains, cannot receive from it any other trouble but that of this Sent, which yet oon paeth away, this Salt leaving afterwards a aline and very agreeable tate; yet notwithtanding many perons, offended with the piercing odour, which is firt perceived in this Salt, and beides diatisfied with its eay Avolation, unles it be extreamely well cloed, have endeavoured to fix it, and o to free it from this mel, not conidering that this mel cannot be altogether eparated from this Salt, but its vertue mut be o too, and that the fixation changes its nature: And intead of contenting
themelves to rectify it well, thereby to carry away, as much as may be, the adventitious mel, which it may have acquired by the violence of the fire by the firt ditillation, they have ometimes altogether detroyed it, and have dealt with it, as if one would deprive Muc and Amber-gris of their good ent, and Coloquintida of its bitternes; and many compounds of their operations, which would not be what they are, if you hould robb them of the leat of thoe parts that compoe them.

We ay therefore, that after the Rectification of this Volatil Salt, (uch an one as we hall et down beneath,) the bet and uret preparation would be, to do nothing ele to it, but to make it to be ued in that condition, only mixing with it things accomodated to the Patients tate, or with uch other remedies, as do not change its nature, nor make it looe any thing of its force or vertue.

If the Fixed Salt of Vipers were capable to arret and retain the Volatil, there were then nothing to be aid againt this fixation, becaue having been both formed jointly and in the ame body, they
have no averion to, but rather are able to help one another; But this common origin, and this friendhip which they have contracted, whilt they lived together in one and the ame ubject, hinders them from detroying one another, and maketh, that what is Fixe can nor will change the nature of the Volatil. And indeed, although you mixe them together, and that the quantity of the Fixe be five or ix times greater than that of the Volatil, and that they may alo lodg with one another; yet they both equally keep their nature and vertue, and they may be eparated by fire, and manifet at all times their everal and ditinct vertues. But this hinders not the taking one Salt among the other, nor that the Fixe hould not then borrow omewhat of the ubtilty of the Volatil, the better to penetrate the Entrals and Veels, to open the more vigorouly the obtructions, and to expel the impurities, it meets with, by iege or urine; and that, on the contrary, the Volatil Salt, helped by the Fix't Salt, hould not carry away and drive out through the pores of the skin or other ways, the more gros and more vicous parts of the humors, that perhaps might
have ecaped its quick and ubtile operation: For which ues, both Salts may be mix'd together upon occaion, without undertaking an impoible fixation.

But epecially, the fixing of this Volatil Salt by Quick-lime cannot pas with all Artits but for an operation altogether detructive to it; and 'tis that, which is mot of all to be avoided, becaue not only it carries away the mel, tate, and vertues of this Salt, but quite changeth its nature, and converts it into its own, by petrifying the ame.

The Fixation of this Volatil Salt, by the Spirit of Salt, although it eem to detroy it and change its nature, in that it carries away the mel and tate of the Volatil Salt, may notwithtanding be admitted rather than the other, in regard that the Spirit of Salt, by preerving the vertue it hath to open all the obtructions of the inward parts, working upon the Volatil Salt, may appropriate to it elf omething of its vertue, epecially that which is able to econd its action, and to expel together with it, by urine or other ways, the mot tenacious and mot tubborn humors. Thoe that would expel the humors
by thee ways, may uefully prepare it after this manner.

Mix four ounces of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, well rectifyed, with four ounces of Water; put them into a Glas-Cucurbite Somewhat high, of a narrow mouth, broad and flat towards the bottom, holding about two pints. Fit to its mouth a Glas-funnel, the end of whoe pipe is very narrow: Lute the funnel quite round about the orifice of the Cucurbite, o that there may be no other aperture but that of the end of the funnel. Then powre, little by little, and drop-wie, ome Spirit of Salt well rectified upon the Volatil Salt. At firt there will be a conflict betwixt them, which will caue an ebullition, but that of a hort duration. Continue to powre upon it of the ame Spirit of Salt, gently and leiurely, according as you find the ebullition ceae, and by intervals tir alo the Cucurbite; and repeat this o often, that at lat there appear no motion any more, and the Spirit of Salt have as 'twere mortified and fixed the Volatil Salt. Then place the Cucurbite in ome receptacle furnih't with Sand; fit to it a head, lute it (though at
the beginning that be not neceary) and by a low fire draw away all the moiture of the Spirit of Salt, and of the Volatil Salt, which will rie almot inipid. Continue the fire till, and when you hall perceive a tate of the Spirit of Salt in what hall be ditill'd, change the Recipient, increae a little the fire, and drive it (yet without too much violence,) until there ditil no more, and that the Salt remain at the bottom of the Cucurbite altogether dry and of a gray colour. You'l find in the Recipient a Spirit of Salt of the ame tate, of the ame colour, and of the ame force it had when it was powr'd upon the Volatil Salt; but you hall not find any part of the Volatil Salt rien to the head, nor to the top of the Cucurbit, as ome have given out it doth, without having experimented it, as we have done. The gray Salt, found at the bottom, is but in a mal quantity, being leen'd almot of two thirds: It's tate is very harp, biting, and much differing from what it had before it was fix'd, and as 'twere mortified by the Spirit of Salt. After this you may diolve this Salt in water, filter it, and make it evaporate, and letting it cool,
you'l find at the bottom a mal quantity of Salt coagulated in the form of Chrytals. Powr out by inclination the water wimming on the top, to have the Salt by itelf, which you may dry in the Air, or the Sun, or over a little fire. You may alo make good ue of the Salt that hall have remained in the water that wam a top, by making it evaporate in part, Chrytallizing and drying it, as the former. You might, if you pleaed, very well omit luting the Funnel upon the Cucurbit, when you will powre the Spirit of Salt upon the Volatil Salt; foramuch as we have found by experiment, that in the operation of the Spirit of Salt upon the Volatil Salt, there rieth nothing but phlegme, that hath neither vertue nor mel; although the ame perons, that have err'd in many things in the rectification of the Volatil Salt, have fear'd they hould looe therein a Volatil Spirit, which was only in their imagination: And the luting, which we have advied, was only to prevent peoples belief, that a part of the Volatil Salt might have ecaped that way.

But although this Volatil Salt appear fix't, and remain as uch at the bottom of
the Cucurbit, after ditillation, yet there is a part, which retakes its former nature, and becoms Volatil again, if it be mix'd with Salt of Tartar, or with ome other Lixiviate Salt, putting them together in a ubliming veel. For thee Lixiviate Salts, being of a nature contrary to acid Salts and Spirits, do mortify them and retain them to themelves, and let go the Volatil Salts, which the acid pirits had, as 'twere, mortified and fix'd, and all that was Volatil in this eemingly fix't Salt, rieth in a white form, and hath almot the ame tate and the ame other qualities of the Volatil Salts well rectified. Yet you will alo find there a great diminution of its weight, o that it will be more advantagious to keep it in the condition, it was in before this lat ublimation; the greatet advantage of which is, to come to know, that the fixation, that hath been made by the Spirit of Salt, although it have as 'twere changed the nature of the Volatil Salt, and hid its diaphoretique quality under that of the diuretique, yet hath not quite detroyed it, ince there is ome part, that can retake its pritine form and vertue.

This Salt thus fix'd poeeth the vertues of a Spirit of Salt concentred, but they are found augmented by thoe, it hath borrowed from the Volatil Salt. Thoe, who would only carry away, by urine or iege, the uperfluous humours of the body, may uefully prepare and employ it; but thoe, that hall ue the Volatile Salt well rectified, without changing its nature, nor diverting its action by any fixation, will finde therein uch effects, as will be incomparably more apparent and more enible, and will not wate of it o much.

div.head: CHAPT. VIII.
Of the Vertues of the Volatile Salt of Vipers, and of what the other parts, eparated by Ditilla on, may perform.
div.p:
THE Volatile Salt of Vipers is to be conider'd, as a Sun, as well among the parts, that rie by ditillation, as among thoe that ret in the Retort; there being none among thoe that are come over, but have borrowed from it almot all the vertue it can have; nor any of thoe that have tay'd, but have need of it, or are ueles without it. The Flegm that rieth firt, carries alwayes ome part with it, without which it would produce no effect. That which is called Spirit, is nothing ele, to peak aright, but a Volatile Salt, which in the ditillation
hath been followed by a little Flegme diolving it, and giving it the form of a Spirit: which may be hewed by the Rectification, wherein that aline volatil part is eparated, raied, and coagulated into a white and chrytalline forme, and leaveth at the botom of the cucurbite the moiture that had changed its nature, and is nothing ele but flegm. We ay, on this occaion, the ame thing of what many Authors improperly call the Volatil Spirit of an humane skull, of Harts-horn, and of other parts of Animals, they being nothing ele but Volatil Salts mixt with flegme, which they afterwards quit, when they are rectified. The Oyle alo would have but very little vertue, if it borrowed no Volatil alt, and if it retained not in it a good part thereof, as may be oberved in the Rectification: for, if the Oyle were meaur'd, or weighed, before 'tis put among the ret into the cucurbite for rectification, and if it were weighed again after that all the Volatil Salt is rien, it would be found much diminihed in quantity, and in trength alo, becaue mot of the Volatil Salt, which had joyned it elf to it, hath been carried away by the rectification.
So thoe, that eparate the Oyle from the other parts to rectify them, and who ue it not but for wounds or ulcers, and to take away uperfluities, do doubtles not know it aright; for it is alo endow'd with other vertues more coniderable; of which we hall peake in this Chapter. The Fixt Salt, which rets in the Retort, mix't among the terretrial part, although it is to be put in the rank of Lixiviat Salts, and poeeth few other qualities, but thoe of Salt of Tartar, yet retains omething of the nature of the Volatile alt. And thoe, that have conidered this Salt as a Cautick, have had good ucces with it, without knowing its nature, eing they imputed it to the maligne parts, which they believed to be in Vipers, whereas they hould have acribed it to the nature of Lixiviate alts. But this Salt being taken at the mouth, will be much more effectual, if you mingle ome Volatil Salt with it; this Cautique faculty not hindring but that it may be taken afely and beneficially in appropriated liquors, as many other lixiviate Salts are.

The Terretrial part hath nothing in it, that deerves to be conidered, and it may
jutly be called Terra mortua, Dead earth, after it is freed from its fixed Salt. So that all the parts, that rie by ditillation, as well as thoe that cannot rie, are of mall force, or altogether ueles, without the Volatil Salt. It is therefore upon good reaon, that we attribute to it the principal vertues, which a Viper can furnih.

The imilitude of ubtance, which the Volatile Salt of Viper hath with the pirituous parts of our Body, conjoyn'd to its ubtile and piercing quality, maketh, that accommodating itelf to their condition, and finding all liberty in its actions, it produceth all the effects, it is capable of, and penetrateth without any oppoition into the most ecret and the mot remote parts of the Body. It hath this peculiar, that thought it act as a Soverain, and finde nothing of reitance to its dominion, yet it exercieth it not as a Conquerour, nor as a Detroyer, but rather as a Retorer of the places and parts, where it paeth; and although all its coures be extraordinary
<> precipitate, yet they are o well
<> and o well directed, that no part
<…> ody mieth them, and that none of <…> is unueful, but rather very beneficial
to all the places, where it paeth.

Now ince the fleh, the heart, the liver, and the other parts of the Viper, taken as an Aliment, or as a Medicine, may erve for the cure of many maladies, and produce very coniderable effects; 'tis not at all tobe doubted, but that this Salt, which is the mot ubtile and the mot potent of them all, is omething more ublime and more efficacious. And we are aur'd, that if it were well known to us, it would pas for an almot Univeral medicine; men would be careful of preparing it, and we hould ee it often precribed by Phyitians, and find it ucceed in innumerable obtinate dieaes, that are but eldom and difficultly cured.

To Judge well of the Effects, which this Volatile Salt can produce in our Bodies, we mut know its manner of operation, which is, to open, to comminute, to attenuate, to pierce, and to drive to the extreme parts of the Body, and through the pores of the skin, all the impurities, and all the trange bodies, that can get out by thoe wayes. Further, it is an enemy to all corruption, very friendly and very agreable
to our nature, which it aits and fortifies, enabling it to expell, not onely by the pores of the skin, but alo by iege and urine, and by all the Emunctories of the Body, the uperfluous humors, which molet it: Whence it comes to pas, that it produces admirable effects upon a thouand occaions, curing a great number of icknees, or at leat giving great relief therein, even in thoe, that are mot refractory, and mot difficult to cure; uch as are Apoplexies, Lethargies, Convulions, Palies, and many other maladies, believed to have their ource in the Brain. It is alo a great relief to the Ditempers of the Breat, as Swoundings, Palpitations of the Heart, Difficulties of Breathing, and Pleuriies. Beides it particularly untops the Obtructions of the Liver, Spleen, Meentery, and other parts of the lower Belly. It diipates all inward impotumes, in their rie, and dilodgeth ecret and unknown pains, which have their origin in the Spirits. It helps digetion, the purification of the mas of the blood, and its ditribution to all the parts of the Body, and reolves and prevents coagulations: And o being an Enemy to all corruption, it is very proper
for all orts of Fevers, caued thereby; as for mot intermittent Feavers, and particularly Quartans. It alo worketh powerfully in the ditempers of the Matrix; and is a remedy to all the vices of the skin, and to the Leproy it elf: but above all, 'tis pecifique againt all Bitings and tingings of venomous creatures, againt all venoms and poyons, if they be not corroive; for in that cae, recoure mut preently be had to Vomitives and to Unctuous things, after which it produceth good effects. It hath a particular vertue againt the Plague, againt all Contagious dieaes, and Epidemical ones, uch as are the Meaels, Small Pox, and the like. In a word, the Inductions, we can draw from the great number of Experiments, we have een of it, at different times, oblige us to affirm, that its vertues goes beyond what can be expreed. And thoe, that hall make reflexion on what we have aid of it, will be able to apply and ue it beneficially to many other icknees, which to enumerate would be too prolix and too tedious.

In the mean time, we cannot forbear to relate here a very remarkable Experiment, made upon a Gentleman, who uffered
about a month ince, a violent and continual paine, doubled and redoubled, at the right part of his front pretty near the Temple: the end of a finger might cover the place of the pain; there appeared no rednes nor welling, and there was perceived no hardnes. Yet the pain, though it was, as 'twere, fixed in a point, was communicated to the other neighboring parts, o that the Gentleman could not chew, nor o much as open his mouth to take down a little broth, but with extreme pain, though hunger urged him. The Phyitians, that aw him, had ued everal means to relieve him, and, among the ret, Venae-ections in the arm and foot; they had purged him often; they had employed frictions of his neck and houlders; they had applyed to him Veicatories, and Snailes, behind his eares: they had caued his temporal artery to be open'd, and drawn from him ten or twelve ounces of arterial blood, and then cauteried the Aperture; they had alo precribed him powerful Sudorifiques, which were continued many dayes morning and evening, and had made him weat very copiouly; and the Patient himelf, of his own accord, being extremely preed
by the violence of the pains, caued one of his upper teeth, which was very ound, to be pulled out, hoping thereby to give ome vent to them: But after he had ued all thee means in vain, one doe of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, given in wine, remov'd preently all the pain, which caued as great a wonder in the Aitants, as atisfaction in the Patient. This o urpriing effect, which demontrateth better, than all reaons, the force and efficacy of this Volatil Salt, may alo conclude the dicoure of its Vertues.

There remains now, that we ay omething of the vertues of the Oyle, which rieth by Ditillation with the Volatil Salt, of which it alo retains a part. Its trong ent is the caue, that it is not often employed; whence it comes, that ometimes it is more advantageous to the Preparer, to profit by the rectification of the Volatil Salt, which it hath, than to keep it in its condition for Patients that hall ue it notwithtanding its trong mel and ill tate. This mel is o intimately ticking to it, that there is no rectification, able to remove it. But we make herewith known to all thoe, that hall be able to
comply with the ue of it, that it is one of the bet and mot efficacious outward remedies in all Phyick, provided it be made ue of, when 'tis yet indued with its Volatil Salt: For it opens, attenuates, reolves, is abterive, and admirably cleaning; and we know, who have experimented it, that the continued anointing with it, accompanied with the internal ue of the Volatil Salt, produceth admirable effects in the parts labouring under the Paly, and deprived of motion, and even in thoe, that are dryed for want of the communication of Spirits and nourihment. A little Spunge imbibed with this Oyl, carried in a little box pierced, and often melled to, is very good in the time of the Plague, to keep off the ill Air, and to fortify the Brain, and the noble parts. It is alo good to make it to be melled, to put of it in the notrils, and to annoint the Temples with it, in Epileptical Symptoms, and for thoe, that are troubled with giddines, and have their Brain charged with vapors or flegme; for it gives them vent, and dipels them powerfully. It hath alo a coniderable effect againt the uffocations of the Matrix,
and againt all orts of worms; in which cae, ome drops of it may even be given at the mouth, in wine, or broth; and the hollow of the tomach anointed therewith. It viibly diipitateth all outward contuions, and erveth much for inward ones, and epecially for thoe of the Head. It reolves tumours and hardnees, giving iue by the pores to uch matter, as can tranpire, digoting the greer, and bringing them to a laudable uppuration. It is alo abterive and cleaneth all orts of Ulcers, and healeth all the ditempers of the skin, even the mot tubborn, provided the internal caue thereof be removed. In all which evils its effects are yet more quick and powerful, if it be enforced by the internal ue of the Volatil Salt, which, in a word, is that, which gives it its main vertue.

We hall add, on this occaion, that the Ancients valued very much their Oyl of Vipers, which they prepared everal ways, ome by infuion, ome by the decoction of Vipers in Oyl of Oliues. If they had rightly proportioned the quantity of Vipers with that of the Oyl; if they had added thereto what moiture was neceary; and
if in this they had employed ome good method, this Oyl might produce good effects, and we hould approve of it, and refer our Readers to it. But finding nothing regular in all the Preparations, by them decribed, we thought good here to et down one, according to all the rules of Art.

Take about the end of May, or the beginning of June, a dozen great Vipers newly taken, cut each of them into even or eight pieces, and put them into a well glazed and trong earthen pot: powr upon them three pounds of Oyl of Olives, and one pint of white wine; cover the pot well, and make it boyl over a gentle fire to the conumption of the moiture. Then train all, queeze out the Vipers well, and keep the Oyle for ue. In the mean time, fear not (as the Antients did) the Vapors, that may iue out of the pot during the decoction; for the Vipers, as we have aid, have no poyon in all their body. This Oyle, thus prepared, hath not, 'tis true, all the trength and vertues of the ditilled Oyle, of which we were peaking a little before; but it may very well erve for an oyntment in all the ditempers
of the skin, in contractions of nerves, in rheumatimes, & in many other evils.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Manner of uing the Volatil Salt.
div.p: ALthough it be impoible to pecify in particular all the wayes of Uing the Volatil Salt of Vipers, no more than one can well enumerate the icknees, that may have need of it; Yet, in ome degree to atisfy thoe that may deire it we hall make here an Abridgment of a good part of what we have een practi'd by Phyitians, that perfectly know the qualities and proprieties of this Salt, and ue it daily to the great benefit of their Patients.

You mut firt know, that its piercing Tate hinders it from being given alone, and that it mut be mix't, now with ome
Aliment, as in broth, the yolk of an egg, a roted apple, a little jelley, &c. ometimes with Medicines, and that innumerable wayes, which partly depend from the humour and dipoition of the Patient, but chiefly from the wit, knowledge, and dicretion of the Phyitian. For this Salt calls for a Phyitian, that hath ufficient ability to know and meaure its force and activity; that is intelligent and vered in all Maladies, to be able beneficially to employ it in thoe that require it, that knows to chue a favorable time and occaion; and to mix it pertinently and to good purpoe with uch things, as may not change its nature nor divert its operation, nor ubvert the indication, he hall have taken. So that 'tis neceary, to be equally aur'd of the genuine and methodical preparation of the Salt; of the knowledge of its qualities and vertues; of the nature of the ditemper, of the condition, temper, and trength of the Patient; of the fitnes of its exhibition among aliments or appropriated medicaments, and of the occaions and the time, in which it may be uefully employed. And when a due regard hath been had to all thee circumtances, men
will not fail to finde very good effects of it. But that thoe, who are not accutom'd to make ue of it, may not unawares finde in it effects contrary to the nature of this Salt, we have thought ourelves obliged to advertie them, that they mut above all things avoid mixing them among Acids, and epecially among Spirit of Salt, Vitriol, Brimtone, and the like, which would fix it and detroy its operation. To find therefore facility in its exhibition, it may be taken in ditilled waters, or ptiane, or uch decoctions as are appropriated to the dieae; as alo in Juleps, Emulions, or Potions diverly compoed. It may alo be mix't in Conerves, Extracts, Confections, and the like; as alo in Lozenges and Opiats, diverly made according to the nature of the ditemper, and the intention of the Phyitian; It is alo mingled with Purgatives, Sudorifiques, Aperitives and Diuretiques; and no les, with its own fix't Salt, and uch other Salts, as are not contrary to it. It is alo given in Wine, and among certain Mineral waters. It may be adminitred to both exes, and to all ages, at all times and hours, between meals according to the nature of
the dieae, and the intention of the Doctor. It may be taken, if one will, everal times in a day, and even at night; and the ue of it may be continued for a good while.

As to its doe, that is different, according to the occaion, age, temper and humour of the Patient, and the nature of the ditemper, and the reiteration made of it: For, the doe is to be much les for thoe, who take it often in one day, and continue the ue of it, than for thoe, that take it but once in a cae of need. Sometimes 'tis eteemed ufficient to give 6. 8. 10. or 12. grains of it; but on certain occaions we may give 20. or 25. grains, and ome-times, half a drachme, and even a whole drachme. But dicretion and skill is to be ued; without which, this Salt, as excellent as 'tis, may produce effects quite contrary to what the Phyitian and the Patient might expect from it.

div.head: CHAPT. X.
Divers Remedies or Compoitions, of which the Volatil Salt of Vipers is the Bae or Ground.
div.p:
WE had not undertaken to decribe the vertues, nor the Ues of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, no more than of the Fix't Salt, and of the Oyle that rieth by Ditillation, if this our Book were only written for the skilful Phyitian, who perfectly knows all, and epecially the parts that may be drawn from the Viper. But being deirous to do a good office to uch perons, as have no knowledg thereof, or that knowing it in part, have need to be directed, epecially in the exhibition of this Volatil Salt; we thought good to conclude this Book with the Receipts of
the chief Compoitions of which this Volatil Salt may be the Ground, which are not found in Books, and may produce Effects worthy of this Salt.

And knowing, that there are many curious perons, who having a great eteem for the Viper and its ues, make preparations thereof in private, following the Receipts they find in Books, which ometimes are well, ome-times ill precribed, or ill executed; Wet all impart to them an Elixir of Vipers, that hall be of great vertue, pleaant to the tate, of eay preparation, and of long duration.

Take four douzen of Hearts and as many Livers of Vipers, dry'd in the hade, and reduced to powder; two drachmes of good Cinnamon, half a drachme of Cloves, groly beaten: put them into a trong glas-bottle, holding about two pints. Powr on it a pound of the Queen of Hungary's Water, a pound of Melie-water, half a pound of Orange-flower-water, and half a pound of Roe-water. Cloe the bottle exactly, and expoe it to the Sun for fourty dayes; after which diolve in the liquor a pound of fine Sugar, and pas all through a clean bagg. Put up
this Elixir in a Bottle, and add to it half an ounce of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, well rectified, twelve grains of Levant-Musk, and as much of Amber-gris. Cloe the bottle exactly, and you may keep this Elixir, to ue it in time of need, from half a poonfull to a whole. You may take of it in the morning upon an empty Stomack, and at all hours, according as neceity hall require. This medicin is very good and very convenient: It is not onely proper againt all Poyons, againt the Plague, and all Contagious and Epidemical dieaes, but it alo fortifieth all the noble parts, preerves the Natural heat in good condition, and by this means the ue of it conduces much to preerve Health, and to prolong Life.

The Elixir following deerveth alo to be communicated to the Public, as a medicine that is not common, and is very available, not onely for the Sicknees of men, as well in the Brain, as the tomack, and all the noble parts; but alo very particularly, for mot of the dieaes of Women. I hall give you here the Decription of it. Take an ounce of good Saffron, as much of fair Myrrhe, as much of Aloes
Socotrina, and the ame quantity of White Amber; a drachm of the Extract of Opium, and as much of the Extract of Cator. Mingle your Extracts in a little Spirit of Wine; pulverize all the ret; and put altogether in a Glas-Body: powr upon it three pounds of Spirit of wine tartarized; place the Body in a Bath of Ahes; fit an Head to it, with its Recipient, well luted together: Give it a moderate fire, and draw from it about the moiety of the Spirit of Wine; then unlute your veels, decant the tincture, that will wim above your powders, which will be found very much imbued with all their qualities; and keep it by itelf in a bottle well-cloed. Powre the Spirit of Wine, which you have drawn off, upon the remainder in the Body; Fit again to it the Head and the Recipient, and draw again from it the half of the Spirit of Wine. Decant again the tincture wimming a top, mingle it with the firt, and keep it likewie. Cohobate for the third time the Spirit of wine, drawn off, upon the remainder in the Body; proceed as before, and powre off the tincture wimming a top, and mingle it with the former: then filter all three
together, and powre all into a trong Viall, adding to the whole an ounce of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, which will eaily diolve in it; keep the whole thus mix't and well cloed. The doe may be from ten to ixteen drops.

We hall yet adde to this an Opiate of great efficacy for mot ditempers of the Brain; and tis this. Take half an ounce of the Extract of the root and eed of the male-Paeony; and of the true Mieltoe of the Oak, and of that of Betony-flowers, and of that of Clove-gilly-flowers, the ame quantity of each of them; three drachms of the Confection of Alkermes of Meue, three drachms of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, one drachme of the Volatil Salt of Succinum, two drachms and an half of prepared Pearl, and as much of Crabs-eyes prepar'd; three drops of Cinamon-oyle, and as much of the oyle of Mace: Mingle all according to Art, and make an Opiate of it, and keep it in a pot of Fayence (a ort of fine white Earthen pots) well cloed. The doe of it may be from a cruple to a drachme.

You may alo make, in the following manner, an opening and laxative Opiate,
that hall conduce to the cure of undry long and tubborn dieaes, epecially of thoe that are caued by everal obtructions of the parts. Take of the Conerve of Tamarisk-flowers, of the Conerve of the Flowers of Genita or Spanih-Broom, of that of Mary-gold, and of that of the Male-peach flowers, of each ix drachms; half an ounce of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, as much of the Extract of the ordinary Iris root, and as much of the Extract of Rubarb; two drachms of the fix't Salt of Vipers, as much of the Mineral Bezoar, and as much of the Salt of Worm-wood; a drachme and an half of Roin of Scammony, and as much of the Extract of Coloquintida; and a drachme of the powder of Cinnamon. Mix all thee things together, and adding to it, as much as needs, of the Syrup of Succory, compounded with Rubarb, you hall make an Opiate of it, the Doe of which may be from one drachme to two, and even to three for tronger Bodies.

There may alo be made Pills, that hall have a vertue near the former in efficacy, to be taken in a les quantity. Take of the Extract of Aloes, made with the juyce
of the cleaned flowers of Violets, of the Extract of Rubarb, and of that of the Levant-Sena, of each two drachms; as much of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, as much of the Roin of Scammony, and as much of the Gumm Ammoniac in drops; one drachme of Mineral Bezoar, and the like quanitty of the Fixt Salt of Vipers. Reduce all into a mas of Pills, of which the doe hall be from half a cruple to two cruples.

Thoe, whoe tomach hall be troubled with tenacious humors, uch as could not be carryed away by Purges, or other remedies; thoe, that have a naueounes, and are ubject to troubleome reentments from the Stomach, may to good purpoe ue the following powder.

Take of Coriander-eed (that is not prepared with Vinegar, according to the ill way of the Antients, but uch as is old in good hops,) of Anis-eed, of weet Fennel-eed, of the root of Lickorih well craped and dryed, of each half anounce; three drachms of the Volatil Salt of Vipers, and as much of Crabs-eyes prepared; two drachms of the Fixt Salt of Vipers, and as much of well-choen Cinamon. Bring all
to a fine powder, and adde to it its weight, or if you will, double its weight of fine powder'd ugar. Cloe this mixture in a Glas-veel, or in one of the fine white Earthen pots, and cloe it carefully. You may take of it, at a time, from half a poonfull to a whole, according as you have put more or les Sugar to it. You may alo adde to the powder ome drops of the Oyl of Anis, and of the Oyl of Cinnamon, and even of Musk and Ambre-gris.

This Volatil Salt is to very good purpoe mix't among the Sneezing powders; for beides that it penetrates exceedingly by its activenes, it alo dicharges the Brain powerfully, and withall fortifieth it. It may be mixed with the powders of Betony, Marjoram, Roemary, Arabic, Staechas, Sage, and the like, not putting but a ixth part of our Volatil Salt among thee powders.

Thoe that would have an Opiate, proper not onely to fortify the Heart, the Stomach, and all the noble parts, but alo to expell all kind of Venom, and all the impurities of the mas of Bloud, and of the olid parts, and to make them iue out at the pores of the skin, or at the other emunctories,
may prepare very beneficially the following Opiate.

Take two ounces of the Conerve of Gilly-flowers, one ounce of the Confection of Alkermes, ambred and musked, ix drachms of the Volatile Salt of Vipers well rectified, half an ounce of the Confection of Hyacinth, as much of the Electuary of Diacordium, three drachmes of the Mineral Bezoar; and of Pearl prepar'd, of Crabs-eyes prepared, of the Extract of Angelica, and of that of Carlina, of each of thee the ame quantity; two drachms of the Salt of Carduus Benedictus. Mix all together, and reduce it to an Opiate, by adding to it ome Syrup of kermes, or the Clove-Gilly-flowers, as much as needs to give a good conitence to the Compoition: Which you are to keep cloe for your occaions. You may take of it, for a preervative, half a drachm, at a time, in Wine, or broth; but in urging icknees, you may take of it a whole drachme, and even two drachms.

Thoe that will ue the Oyl which hath been drawn by Ditillation, may either employ it all alone, or mingle it with an equal quantity of Unguentum Martiatum, and
even adde to it Oyles ditilled of Roemary, Sage, Lavender and the like.

Thoe, that hall well conider thee Receipts, will finde therein not onely a fit proportion in the doe of all the particulars, but alo great cautiounes in mixing nothing with them, that may detroy or change the natnre of our Volatil Salt; which is the thing, mot to be avoided in the exhibition.

We might here adde many other Compoitions, of which the Volatil Salt of Vipers may be the Ground; but we have contented ourelves to deliver thee for examples, knowing, that there may be found divers others, good enough, in Books, and eteeming, that 'tis better to prepare them upon occaion according to exigency, and following the Receipts, which able Phyitians may precribe thereof.

We have alo explain'd ourelves ufficiently in all particulars. We would have been more large, if we had not apprehended we might exceed our bounds, and undertake things, which might be thought to be beyond our reach, and to belong onely to knowing Phyitians.
